sense.def: cloth
dictionaryExamples: a light/cotton fabric
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: In our country fabric seldom could be obtained. My mother made herself a winter jacket from old curtains and black stockings from an old woolen pullover. 
 Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: the basic way in which a society or other social group is organized
dictionaryExamples: The family is part of the fabric of society.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You cannot infringe individual liberties and ban the purchase of cars - it would go against the very fabric of modern society. International English Language Testing System; C2; Romanian

sense.def: extremely good
dictionaryExamples: They've got a fabulous house.
We had an absolutely fabulous vacation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Everybody admitted that the entertainment was absolutely fabulous. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: the front part of the head, where the eyes, nose and mouth are, or the expression on this part
dictionaryExamples: She's got a long, thin face.
She had a worried expression on her face.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  She has got brown [e]yes, [a] round face and wh[ite] s[k]in. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Urdu

sense.def: to show with your face that you do not like someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Joe made a face when he saw what was for lunch.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Making a face, I slapped my forehead. Preliminary English Test; B1; Assamese

sense.def: If you accept something at face value because of the way it first looks or seems, you do so without thinking carefully about it.
dictionaryExamples: You can't just accept everything you read in the newspapers at face value.
These results should not be taken at face value - careful analysis is required to assess their full implications.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People are assessed at face value [by] the type of cars they drive. International English Language Testing System; C1; Amharic

sense.def: to become less respected by others because of  something you did
dictionaryExamples: She had to find a way to accept defeat without losing face.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, many popular people like Pierce Brosnan managed to keep their lives out of the press and yet be present to meet public demand without losing face. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to manage to stop yourself from smiling or laughing
dictionaryExamples: I can never play jokes on people because I can't keep a straight face.

sense.def: used when you are describing how a situation seems on the surface
dictionaryExamples: On the face of it, this seems like a bargain, but I bet there are hidden costs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the face of it, both sides have valid arguments, and it's a difficult balancing act to manage. International English Language Testing System; C2; Urdu

sense.def: while having to deal with a difficult situation or problem
dictionaryExamples: They left home in the face of strong opposition from their families.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: No doubt, it was rather difficult to like Enid X. She was hardly likely to arouse sympathy in anybody even in the face of death. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to be the opposite of what is usual or accepted
dictionaryExamples: These recommendations fly in the face of previous advice on safe limits of consumption.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But when we have a look outside our wonderful world, we can easily see that this argument flies in the face of the facts. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: something someone does that insults or upsets you
dictionaryExamples: After all that hard work, losing my job was a real slap in the face.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My father noticed that and decided it was high time to take me down a peg or two. He used to work as a volunteer in [a] hospital for children dying for cancer. One day, he took me there. It was like a slap in the face - suddenly I saw a different world. It was a bleak world, without smiles and happy faces. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to be or turn in a particular direction
dictionaryExamples: Our house faces north/south/east/west.
She turned to face him.
The café faces (towards) the sea.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is  a desk [to] the right of the room which faces my bed. Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish

sense.def: If you face a problem, or a problem faces you, you have to deal with it.
dictionaryExamples: This is one of the many problems faced by working mothers.
Passengers could face long delays.
You're faced with a very difficult choice there.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Grandparents are experienced people and they can help their child[ren] to avoid a lot of problems which they have faced. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to not want to do something or deal with someone, often because it is difficult or unpleasant
dictionaryExamples: I can't face walking up all those steps again.
I knew someone had to tell her but I couldn't face it.
How can I face him now that he knows what I've done?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Everybody at [the] swimming pool was laughing about me. I couldn't face my family. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to accept that something unpleasant is true and start to deal with the situation
dictionaryExamples: I think Phil has to face the fact that she no longer loves him.
We have to face facts here - we simply don't have enough money.
He's dying but he refuses to face the truth.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But Mary has a strong personality, she faces the facts. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to accept punishment or criticism for something bad that you have done
dictionaryExamples: If she doesn't have a good reason for being late, she'll just have to face the music.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Teenagers who live with their parents have to face the music about the long bills their parents receive monthly! Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: something that you say before you say something that is unpleasant but true
dictionaryExamples: Let's face it, none of us are getting any younger.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Let's face it, a life with [no] physical and mental exercise is something none of us relishes. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to accept that a difficult situation exists
dictionaryExamples: Eventually, he faced up to his money problems.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, she had to face up to the fact that it was her duty to question the serial killer, to find out what his motives were. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: directly, meeting someone in the same place
dictionaryExamples: We need to talk face to face.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I need to talk to her face to face. Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: involving two people who are meeting in the same place
dictionaryExamples: a face-to-face meeting

sense.def: of or on the face
dictionaryExamples: facial expressions/hair
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can still recall the doctor's facial expression when he announced the exciting news [to me]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to make something possible or easier
dictionaryExamples: I will do everything in my power to facilitate the process.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I found that the presentations and talks about CVs and letters of application were really useful, [but] we should have been divided into smaller groups to facilitate conversation. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: the equipment and services provided for a particular purpose
dictionaryExamples: athletic facilities
The exercise facilities at our gym are excellent.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The city has more facilities than the countryside. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: a building or other place provided for a particular purpose
dictionaryExamples: a training/research/medical facility
The team has training facilities in New York and Florida.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover, spending the whole afternoon at [the] lake gives people a chance to try a couple of water sports, which the facility offers. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: a part of a system or machine which makes it possible to do something
dictionaryExamples: an overdraft facility
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would suggest free Internet access as an extra facility in our library. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: something that you know is true, exists, or has happened
dictionaryExamples: I don't know all the facts about what happened.
I'm not angry that you took my car - it's just the fact that you didn't ask me first.
I knew for a fact that she was lying.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I love this book, because it's about history facts and it['s] very interestin[g]. Key English Test; A2; Russian

sense.def: used to emphasize what is really true, or to give more information
dictionaryExamples: We met Rebecca for lunch. In fact, we spent the whole afternoon with her.
I was told there were some tickets left but in fact they were sold out.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The club has its own small clubhouse, with many things in it. For example, there was a big pinball-game and some computers.  In fact it was the best clubhouse I've ever seen. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: used to refer to a situation which is surprising in relation to something that is true or happens
dictionaryExamples: The company has been forced to reduce its price, despite the fact that the offer has been very popular.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The advantages of the kind of life that people ha[d] years ago is that they could eat more fruit and vegetables than us. However, there are advantages for us too, because despite the fact that we eat more fast food, we do more exercise than they [did]. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: real events and experiences, not things that are imagined
dictionaryExamples: It's sometimes hard to separate fact from fiction.

sense.def: used to give more information, or to correct something that has been said
dictionaryExamples: John plays golf professionally. As a matter of fact, he has just won a big competition.
"So you're from Cambridge?" "No, as a matter of fact, I'm from Bristol."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think it would be better to choose somewhere outdoors. As a matter of fact, I prefer the open air and the sunlight! First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: used to tell someone that something is the truth
dictionaryExamples: I wouldn't usually ask for your help, but the fact is I'm desperate.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You may find [it] unusual for a woman to play football, but the fact is I'm Brazilian and in Brazil [it] is really common. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: one of the things that has an effect on a situation, decision, event, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Money was an important factor in their decision to move.
Price is an important/key/major factor in the success of any product.
economic factors
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [Modern technology] is another important factor which affects our life. First Certificate in English; B2; Thai

sense.def: something important that helps to make the final decision
dictionaryExamples: Cost was the deciding factor in choosing this builder.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Personally, I think the quality of teachers, school reputation and facilities should be the deciding factors for parents [for] which schools their children should be educated in. International English Language Testing System; C2; Malay

sense.def: a building or set of buildings where large amounts of goods are made using machines
dictionaryExamples: a car/shoe factory
He works in a paint factory.
a factory worker/manager
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My friend Martin works at a factory. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: teachers at a college or university, or in a department of a college or university
dictionaryExamples: We are interviewing for new faculty - there are two positions open in the history department.
Faculty are opposed to the proposals made by the university administration.

sense.def: the group of teaching staff of a college or university or of a department of a college or university
dictionaryExamples: He was part of the computer engineering faculty before becoming dean of the Graduate School.
Columbia University faculty members
The state university promotes academic diversity among the faculties of the five colleges.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think that the strengths of the system are mainly in high[er] education and in some university faculties. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: to  become less bright, strong or clear, or to make something become less bright, strong or clear
dictionaryExamples: If you hang your clothes out in the bright sun, they will fade.
My suntan is already fading.
They arrived home just as the light was fading.
The music began to fade.
The sun had faded the blue walls.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Since the cottage is quite isolated, the electric power sup[p]ly is not always the best. Anyway, the first night, the lights started to fade. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to gradually become less strong or clear and then disappear
dictionaryExamples: With time, memories of that painful summer would fade away.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: These memories would never fade away, she knew it. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to not pass a test or exam
dictionaryExamples: A lot of people fail their driving test the first time.
If she doesn't study she'll fail all her exams.
"How was your chemistry exam?" "Awful! I think I failed."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was told most people fail the exam two or three times. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: to not do what is necessary or expected
dictionaryExamples: He failed to turn up for football practice yesterday.
He failed to mention that we wouldn't be paid for the work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Your advertisement also failed to mention the fact that there w[ere] no discounts. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to not be successful
dictionaryExamples: She moved to London in the hope of finding work as a model, but failed.
He failed in his attempt to break the record.
This method of growing tomatoes never fails.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I tried to make him give up, but all my attempts failed. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: to stop working normally, or to become weaker
dictionaryExamples: Two of the plane's engines had failed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The sound system failed. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: used to say that you do not accept something
dictionaryExamples: I fail to see why you cannot work on a Sunday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I fail to understand why they still refuse to use this media; it could possibly be the main solution to the present problems [in] the library. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: when someone or something does not succeed
dictionaryExamples: Their attempt to climb Mount Everest ended in failure.
I'm a failure at making cakes.
I feel like such a failure.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: David told her that the reason [for] his failure was her, because she used to press him and she couldn't accept that he wanted to be an actor. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: when you do not do something that you are expected to do
dictionaryExamples: Failure to pay within 14 days will result in interest being charged.
It was his failure to return her phone call that told her that something was wrong.

sense.def: when something does not work, or stops working as well as it should
dictionaryExamples: All street lights aren't working due to a power failure.
He died of heart/liver failure.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [There] has been a power failure but it will be solved in [a] few minutes. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: slight and not easy to notice, smell, hear, etc.
dictionaryExamples: a faint sound/noise/smell
She gave me a faint smile.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I heard a faint sound. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to feel very weak and as if you might fall down
dictionaryExamples: Seeing all the blood made me feel faint.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Starting to feel faint, Fred quickly roused himself and ran out of the hotel as quickly as he could. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: used to emphasize that you do not know something
dictionaryExamples: I haven't the faintest idea what you're talking about.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some twenty years ago, when I left my parents' home to go and live on my own, I was [given] four mugs. By whom? I haven't the faintest idea. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: to suddenly become unconscious for a short time, usually falling down
dictionaryExamples: He faints at the sight of blood.
I nearly fainted in the heat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The young girl was about to faint. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: having pale skin or a light color of hair
dictionaryExamples: She's got fair hair and blue eyes.
He's fair-haired.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is a pretty girl with long fair hair and she has beautiful eyes. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: treating everyone in the same way, so that no one has an advantage
dictionaryExamples: That's not fair! You always go first!
It's not fair to make me do all the work.
a fair trial
I can't spend all my time with one child - it wouldn't be fair to the others.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Even though she thought her mom wasn't being fair, she decided to go and try to have a nice day with her family. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: acceptable, reasonable or right
dictionaryExamples: a fair deal
He offered a fair price for the car.
That's a fair comment/question.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You may ask yourself: "What do you do in a club?" Well, it's a fair question!!! Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: used for saying that you can understand and accept someone's opinion or decision
dictionaryExamples: "He says he'll only work on Sunday if he gets paid extra." "Fair enough."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Most of the streets are open [to] cars and therefore people tend to escape to a little area around the pedestrian streets. Fair enough, but it make[s] those streets terribly overcrowded. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: not very good but not very bad
dictionaryExamples: He’s good in chemistry but only fair in math.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As for grammar, listening and writing skills, they were only fair. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: a large amount, distance, size, etc.
dictionaryExamples: There's still a fair amount of work to be done on the house.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course it is important to find a job we enjoy and which leaves us a fair amount of free time, but it is equally important to find a job that pays the bills, especially nowadays. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: an equal and honest opportunity
dictionaryExamples: All he asks is a fair chance to prove his innocence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then again, I think you have to give every job a fair chance. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: behavior that is fair, honest, and does not take advantage of people
dictionaryExamples: The public needs to feel a sense of fair play from the government.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He still believes in justice or just the rule of fair play. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: an event outside where food and goods are sold, there is entertainment, and sometimes contests
dictionaryExamples: the state/county fair
We spent the afternoon at the street fair on Second Avenue.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The annual Leipzig fair is 500 years old. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: a show in a large place where people who work  in a particular industry or have a particular interest or hobby meet to sell products, share information, give demonstrations, etc.
dictionaryExamples: a book/antiques/toy fair
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The fair was well organized and structured into specific sections from clothing and sportswear to household appliances and electronics. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: more than average, but less than very
dictionaryExamples: a fairly big family
She's fairly tall.
We get along fairly well.
I saw her fairly recently.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The weather was fairly warm. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: If you do something fairly, you do it in a way which is right and reasonable and treats people equally.
dictionaryExamples: He claimed that he hadn't been treated fairly by his employers.
Officials will ensure that the election is carried out fairly.

sense.def: when you treat everyone in the same way, so that no one has an advantage
dictionaryExamples: He believes in fairness and decency.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think you have not treated us with fairness and truthfulness and therefor[e] I do think that an apology in the newspaper would be in order. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: great trust or confidence in something or someone
dictionaryExamples: She has no faith in modern medicine.
You'll be fine - I have a lot of faith in you.
After the trial, his family said they had lost all faith in the legal system.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We must do our best to help [these children] to have faith in their future. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: strong belief in a god or gods
dictionaryExamples: Even in the bad times she never lost her faith.
Her faith in God was shattered when her baby died.
It's my faith that keeps me going.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Your story about Christianity was very interesting and I was shocked at your deep faith in God.

sense.def: a particular religion
dictionaryExamples: the Muslim/Christian/Jewish faith
a multi-faith society
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Everybody was praying, asking for help according to their faith or religion. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: loyal
dictionaryExamples: a faithful friend
His faithful old dog accompanied him everywhere he went.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: An ideal pet should be a faithful friend [to] people, especially [to] its owner. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: If your husband, wife or partner is faithful, they do not have a romantic relationship with anyone else.
dictionaryExamples: a faithful husband
They remained faithful to each other throughout their long marriage.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Making a commitment to be faithful to another, and to love a person for the rest of your life is no small thing. International English Language Testing System; C2; Afrikaans

sense.def: not changing any of the original details, facts, style, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Does the film adaptation stay faithful to the novel?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Working with deconstruction in music, he remained faithful to his main motto: Be yourself, express yourself, never repeat or imitate. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: not real, but made to look or seem real
dictionaryExamples: fake fur
a fake passport
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the walls there are paintings which are very artistic - one of them is a fake Picasso. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: a copy of something that is intended to look real or valuable and deceive people
dictionaryExamples: Experts say that the painting is a fake.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many of the pictures taken are fakes. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: someone who pretends to have particular skills or qualities so that they can deceive people or get their admiration
dictionaryExamples: He said he was a doctor, but we soon realized he was a fake.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So, after all he was a fake! Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: to copy something in order to deceive people
dictionaryExamples: The documents had been faked.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People liked it so much that another author, using the [pseudonym] of "Arellaneda", faked Cervante's novel by writing a second part. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to pretend that something has happened when it has not or to pretend to have a feeling that you do not have
dictionaryExamples: They faked illness to avoid having to work.
He said he was feeling sick, but he was just faking it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This situation lasted about two years until Caroline had a great idea: they would fake their death and run away to live a quiet life on a secret island they would have bought under an alias. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to move down toward the ground, sometimes by accident
dictionaryExamples: The path's very steep, so be careful you don't fall.
He fell and broke his leg.
I fell down the stairs and injured my back.
He fell to his death climbing the Matterhorn.
By winter, all the leaves had fallen off the trees.
The snow had been falling steadily all day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You['d] better wear your cheap clothes as paint may fall on you. Key English Test; A2; Tamil

sense.def: to become lower in size, amount or strength
dictionaryExamples: Demand for new cars has fallen recently.
The quality of his work has fallen during the year.
The temperature could fall below zero tonight.
Average temperatures fell by ten degrees.
The pound has fallen to its lowest-ever level against the dollar.
Stock prices fell sharply this week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It fell steadily until 1960, and remained [at] 3% until 1987. International English Language Testing System; [no level]; Chinese

sense.def: to start to sleep
dictionaryExamples: I fell asleep on the sofa watching TV.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And I need a bookshelf and a lamp of course, because I always read in bed before I fall asleep. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to start to love someone
dictionaryExamples: I was 20 when I first fell in love.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I fell in love with David. Preliminary English Test; B1; Catalan

sense.def: If an event or joke falls flat, it fails to have the effect that you wanted, such as making people laugh.
dictionaryExamples: All the jokes in his speech fell flat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The cultural visits fell flat [in comparison] to their expectations, although the sightseeing tour of Willstown was, as the students said, "fascinating." Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: used to say that it is becoming dark
dictionaryExamples: When darkness fell, I began to feel worried.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He greeted the worms and the slugs, and as darkness fell he retired to the shelter he had built for the night. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: to be defeated and start to be controlled by a different leader
dictionaryExamples: The city fell to the enemy.

sense.def: to become worse, or start to be in a bad situation or condition
dictionaryExamples: Education standards are continuing to fall.
Empty for 30 years, the building had fallen into ruin.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This impressive, massive 18th-century building which accommodated the Town Hall until recently (5 years ago) has now fallen into disuse. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to hang down
dictionaryExamples: Her long hair fell softly over her shoulders.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She had gorgeous black hair falling down her back, a creamy complexion and a figure models dream of. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: If advice or a request falls on deaf ears, people ignore it.
dictionaryExamples: Our pleas for help fell on deaf ears.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His cry for help and for a more meaningful relationship between himself and Mildred invariably fell on deaf ears. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: When events or details that you did not understand before fall into place, they become easy to understand.
dictionaryExamples: When Jo told me she had a twin sister, everything fell into place.

sense.def: to be hurt or deceived by something or someone bad
dictionaryExamples: He fell prey to a gang of criminals pretending to be city officials.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As young people do not have experience in living independently in society and are not fully aware of social problems such as drugs and violence, they may easily fall prey to adults who would like to exploit them. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to not reach a particular level, but only by a small amount
dictionaryExamples: Sales for the first half of this year fell just short of the target.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Furthermore, it cannot be denied that public transport falls short of the target set during the planning process. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swiss German

sense.def: to fail to achieve something
dictionaryExamples: His behavior falls short of what we expect.
She just fell short of the grades she needed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This routine was really wearing me out, but, I didn't want to fall short of my parents' expectations. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to break into pieces
dictionaryExamples: My poor old boots are falling apart.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It looks like it [is] going to fall apart any day. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to start having problems that you cannot deal with
dictionaryExamples: The deal fell apart because of a lack of financing.
His life fell apart when his wife died.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All her dreams and wishes fell apart. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to use someone or something when other things have failed, or when there are no other choices
dictionaryExamples: We've been saving up the past few years, to have something to fall back on.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Moreover, in an emergency, you can fall back on my neighbors. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to fall onto the ground
dictionaryExamples: Our apple tree fell down in the storm.
He stumbled and fell down.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I got up in the morning, I slip[ped] on a piece of soap and fell down. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to suddenly have strong romantic feelings about someone
dictionaryExamples: She fell for a tall, handsome Frenchman when she was on vacation in Paris.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I saw a handsome boy [and] I fell for him. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to argue with someone and stop being friendly with them
dictionaryExamples: She's fallen out with her sister.
They fell out over money.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My husband always blame[s] me and we fall out over my incapacity to cook. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: If someone or something falls over, they fall to the ground or onto their side.
dictionaryExamples: She tripped and fell over.
The fence fell over in the wind.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I nearly fell over because the corridor was very dark. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: If a plan or agreement falls through, it fails to happen.
dictionaryExamples: Our plans to go on vacation together fell through when Jamie got sick.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All our plans fell through and I hope it will never happen to me again. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: the season of the year between summer and winter, when leaves fall from the trees
dictionaryExamples: We like to travel in the fall when there are fewer tourists.
Last fall we went to Vermont.
fall colors/leaves
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You come here in the fall and I think it's best to spend our time in the city be[cau]se [the] countryside is very cold. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: when the size, amount or strength of something gets lower
dictionaryExamples: the recent fall in the price of gas
a fall in the unemployment rate
We could hear the rise and fall of voices in the other room.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is a fall in job vacancies. International English Language Testing System; [no level]; Turkish

sense.def: when someone or something falls down to the ground, often without intending to or by accident
dictionaryExamples: He had a nasty fall and hurt his back.
The boulder smashed several small trees during its fall.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was terrified and I heard the noise of a fall just by my side. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: when a city, government, leader, etc. loses power or control
dictionaryExamples: the fall of the Roman Empire
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After the fall of the previous system everything changed. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: not true or correct
dictionaryExamples: a false name
false information
The rumor turned out to be false.
You'll get a false impression/idea of the town if you only visit the university.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I must say that the advertisement for the show included a lot of false information. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: not real, but made to look or seem real
dictionaryExamples: false eyelashes/teeth
false documents
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The main reason why we want to join your course is in order to learn how to recognize a false stamp. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: not sincere or expressing real emotions
dictionaryExamples: false promises
I hate the way he smiles at everyone. It's so false.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The actor is really getting on my nerves because he is so selfish and so false. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: when you are known by many people because of your achievements, skills, etc.
dictionaryExamples: She first rose to fame as a singer at the age of 16.
She moved to New York in search of fame and fortune.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is certain that these people have fame, fortune and success, and that many of them are very rich. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: easy to recognize because of being seen, met, heard, etc. before
dictionaryExamples: There were one or two familiar faces.
The house looked strangely familiar, though she knew she'd never been there before.
The street was familiar to me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Someone started to wave and then I saw a familiar face. Preliminary English Test; B1; Serbian

sense.def: to know something or someone well
dictionaryExamples: I'm sorry, I'm not familiar with your poetry.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm familiar with many kinds of sports activities such as ball games, recreation games, swimming and Japanese budo-karate, judo etc.  First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: a group of people who are related to each other, such as a mother, a father, and their children
dictionaryExamples: A new family has moved in next door.
I come from a large family - I have three brothers and two sisters.
He doesn't have any family.
His family comes from Ireland.
This movie is good family entertainment.
How does family life suit you?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will come with my family. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Bengali

sense.def: the children of a family
dictionaryExamples: He's a single parent raising a family on his own.
Paul and Alison are hoping to start a family soon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some people also want to [have] a family because they want to be a father or a mother. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: when people living in a particular area do not have enough food for a long time causing suffering and death
dictionaryExamples: The floods were followed by a terrible famine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Pictures of the famine in Africa or the defor[e]station of the Amazon raise important issues for humanity as a whole, urging us to be more active citizens. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: known and recognized by many people
dictionaryExamples: a famous actor
New York is a city famous for its theaters and nightlife.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is the most famous place in Edinburgh. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: someone who admires and supports a person, sport, sports team, etc.
dictionaryExamples: More than 15,000 Liverpool fans attended Saturday's game.
He's a big fan of country music.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm a fan of rock music. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: something that is used to move the air around so that it feels cooler, such as a machine or an object that you move with your hand
dictionaryExamples: There was no air conditioning, just a ceiling fan turning slowly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Since it's quite hot here I brought a fan. I have to use it at night otherwise I can't get to sleep. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: someone whose interest in something or enthusiasm for something is extreme
dictionaryExamples: a religious fanatic
fitness/exercise fanatics
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This can give way to fanatics, religious or politic[al], who may easily influence the frustrated masses into doing something they would under other circumstances refrain from. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: attractive and formal or having attractive decoration and interesting features
dictionaryExamples: I wanted a simple black dress, nothing fancy.
Wow - that's a fancy car!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Men usually wear a tuxedo, and women usually wear fancy dresses. Preliminary English Test; B1; Serbian

sense.def: expensive, fashionable, or of high quality
dictionaryExamples: a fancy hotel/restaurant
I got myself a fancy new smartphone.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We can visit museums, beaches, and go to fancy rest[au]rants for dinner. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: extremely good
dictionaryExamples: You look fantastic in that dress.
We had a fantastic time.
They won a trip? That's fantastic!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The beaches here are fantastic! Key English Test; A2; Catalan

sense.def: extremely
dictionaryExamples: They're fantastically rich.
They're doing fantastically well.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We spent three fantastically romantic days later. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: a situation or event that you imagine, which is not real or true
dictionaryExamples: Steve's favorite fantasy was to own a big house and expensive car.
sexual fantasies
She retreated into  a fantasy world, where she could be anything she wanted.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Reading a book stimulates one's fantasy and imagination. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: at, to or from a great distance in space or time
dictionaryExamples: Is the station far away?
She doesn't live far from here.
How far away does your mother live?
How far is it from Australia to New Zealand?
Baltimore  is not far from Washington.
One day, perhaps far in the future, you'll regret what you've done.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It isn't so far from my house so we can go [on foot]. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: until now
dictionaryExamples: So far we've made eight hundred dollars.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So far I like it here very much. Preliminary English Test; B1; Croatian

sense.def: very much
dictionaryExamples: This car is far better than our old one.
It cost far more (money) than I could afford.
He loses his temper far too often.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think restaurant B is far better than restaurant A. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: used to say that you think something is true, but cannot be sure
dictionaryExamples: As far as I know, he's never been in trouble with the police.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As far as I know, accommodation at Camp California is in tents or log cabins. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

blocks.phrase: as far as sb is concerned

sense.def: used to say what someone's opinion is
dictionaryExamples: It's all over as far as I'm concerned.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As far as I am concerned, Bernard is similar to him. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

blocks.phrase: as far as sth is concerned

sense.def: used to say what you are talking about
dictionaryExamples: As far as sports are concerned, I like tennis and football.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As far as studying abroad is concerned, I totally agree with this idea. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: by a great amount
dictionaryExamples: They are by far the best students in the class.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have traveled to many countries, but New Zealand is by far the best. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: used to talk about how true something is
dictionaryExamples: How far do politicians represent the views of ordinary people?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: How far and to what extent would the characteristics we are born with influence our future development in life? International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: used to tell someone that something is certainly not true
dictionaryExamples: He's not selfish, far from it – he's probably one of the kindest people I know.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Contrary to what you may believe by the title, this is not an article about angels waging war against each other. It is far from it as a matter of fact, unless of c[o]urse you consider high-quality web sites to be your guardian angels. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: not at all something
dictionaryExamples: The situation is far from clear.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The service was far from satisfactory, and to say that the hotel was not at all luxurious, would be putting it mildly. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: used to say that something has gone well until now
dictionaryExamples: It's the first time I've done any decorating, but so far, so good.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So far, so good, only no one told us they held this point of view before the actual christening took place. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: certainly not doing something
dictionaryExamples: Far from being pleased, he was embarrassed by the praise.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Far from asking you to close the airport, which would be quite an irrational request, I am suggesting that you should take some action to improve the situation. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

blocks.phrase: go so far as to do sth

sense.def: to take the extreme action of doing something
dictionaryExamples: He even went so far as to stop her using the telephone.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Our present course of action may go so far as to cause irrevers[i]ble damage not only to our planet but also to the people living upon [it]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to behave in a way that upsets or annoys other people
dictionaryExamples: He's said some stupid things in the past, but this time he's gone too far.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Lucia let her speak and calmly said: "You really have gone too far this time." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: not happening or existing very often
dictionaryExamples: Opportunities like this are few and far between.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Jobs in those days were few and far between and for a number of years he was alternating between temporary jobs and unemployment benefit[s]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: describes the part of something that is most distant from the center or from you
dictionaryExamples: His office is at the far end of the corridor.
The children ran to the far side/corner of the room.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The dark spot at the far end of the wall seemed to be coming after her this time. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

blocks.phrase: be a far cry from sth

sense.def: to be very different from something
dictionaryExamples: Her luxury mansion is a far cry from the house she grew up in.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The museum was a far cry from what we expected. Not only were the machines really old and should have been replaced a long time ago, but they were boring as well. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: used to describe political groups whose opinions are very extreme
dictionaryExamples: He belongs to a far right group.

sense.def: a long distance away
dictionaryExamples: faraway places
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They trans[port] me to faraway places and to a magic world. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: an expression on someone's face that shows that they are not thinking about what is happening around them
dictionaryExamples: He had a faraway look in his eyes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But her most noticeable feature[s] are her large [brown] eyes and her happy smile. Yet, sometimes you could see a faraway look in her eyes. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: the money that you pay for a journey on a vehicle such as a bus or train
dictionaryExamples: Air/Bus/Train fares are going up again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In fact, there are buses (number 843 and 845) which go [to] my village but the bus fare is very expensive for me. First Certificate in English; B2; Thai

sense.def: an area of land with fields and buildings, used for growing crops and/or keeping animals as a business
dictionaryExamples: farm animals
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's very important because I'm going to a farm this weekend and there's nothing to do. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: someone who owns or looks after a farm
dictionaryExamples: a sheep farmer
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The farmer was very friendly and we [spent] the day with him. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: the activity of working on a farm or organizing the work there
dictionaryExamples: modern  farming practices
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am interested in farming and hope to own a farm one day. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to interest someone a lot
dictionaryExamples: Science has always fascinated me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What fascinates me about it is that this style of music allows the artist to bring in crazy new ideas such as African or Indian rhythms. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: extremely interested
dictionaryExamples: They were fascinated by his stories.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am sure you will be fascinated by his work and his multi-faceted character. First Certificate in English; B2; Farsi

sense.def: extremely interesting
dictionaryExamples: a fascinating person/place
I found the movie fascinating.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can enjoy not only Hungarian food but also fascinating Hungarian music. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: when you find someone or something fascinating
dictionaryExamples: Her fascination with fashion started at an early age.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Anyhow, even if you can't grasp the deep meaning behind [the] words, its beautiful rhyme and r[h]ythm will exert a fascination on you. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: a style that is popular at a particular time, especially in clothes, hair, makeup, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Long hair is back in fashion for men.
Fur coats have gone out of fashion.
She always wears the latest fashions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like this present because I love clothes and fashion. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: making and selling clothes
dictionaryExamples: the fashion industry
fashion magazines
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I'm tired, I like reading fashion magazines. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: popular at a particular time
dictionaryExamples: a fashionable nightclub/restaurant
fashionable clothes
It's no longer fashionable to smoke.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are some fashionable cafes, restaurants and museums. Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese

sense.def: moving or happening quickly, or able to move or happen quickly
dictionaryExamples: fast cars
a fast swimmer
Computers are getting faster all the time.
The fast train to London takes less than an hour.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like fast music very much. Key English Test; A2; Gujarati

sense.def: doing or getting the things that lead to rapid success and advancement
dictionaryExamples: Their  hard work and successful software put them in the fast lane.
Fed up with life in the fast lane, Jack gave up his job and moved to the countryside.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, should you ask why people are not happier than before, the answer is that nowadays they spend more hours on work than before because modern life is mostly a life in the fast lane. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a very quick way of achieving or dealing with something
dictionaryExamples: These intensive courses claim to offer a fast track to wealth and success.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If I ever found a job which lives up to these expectations, I would consider myself on [the] fast track already. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: moving or happening quickly
dictionaryExamples: We ran as fast as we could.
The accident was caused by people driving too fast in bad conditions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I rode my bike home as fast as I could. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: in a firm or tight way
dictionaryExamples: He tried to get away, but she held him fast.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thankfully, there are those who still cling to such age-old values as personal contentment and growth, regarding them as the anchors which hold happiness fast. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: completely asleep
dictionaryExamples: I looked into his room but he was still  fast asleep.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then she took a relaxing bath and 20 minutes later she was fast asleep. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to close or attach something together, or to become closed or attached together
dictionaryExamples: Fasten your seat belt.
This shirt fastens at the back.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She fell fast asleep and only woke to the sound of the announcement: "Ladies and gent[le]men fasten your seat belts [-] in a couple of minutes we will be landing in Kingston". First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to attach one thing to another
dictionaryExamples: He fastened the rope to a tree.

sense.def: hot food that can be served very quickly because it is already prepared
dictionaryExamples: fast food restaurants
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We don't eat lots of fast food, us[ual]ly I cook every day. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Slovak

sense.def: Someone who is fat weighs too much.
dictionaryExamples: He eats all the time but he never gets fat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is tall and [a] little b[i]t fat. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French

sense.def: a solid or liquid substance that is taken from animals or plants and used in cooking
dictionaryExamples: This product contains no animal fat.
I only use vegetable fat for cooking.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They should also consum[e] as much salad as they can, due to the fact that it does not contain fat. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: A fatal illness or accident causes death.
dictionaryExamples: This illness is fatal in almost all cases.
the fatal shooting of an unarmed 15-year-old
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Paul  received a fatal shot in [the] head. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: Fatal actions have very bad effects.
dictionaryExamples: He made the fatal mistake/error of believing what they told him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That was a fatal mistake because that [person] was my teacher and he wasn't so pleased about my behavi[o]r. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: what happens to someone, especially something bad
dictionaryExamples: We want to decide our own fate.
His fate is now in the hands of the jury.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: No one as powerless as him deserves this fate. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: a power that some people believe decides what will happen
dictionaryExamples: When we met again by chance in Cairo, I felt it must be fate.
Fate has brought us together.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But, little we did know what fate had in store for us. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: your male parent
dictionaryExamples: My father took me to watch football every Saturday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I got it from my father and mother. Key English Test; A2; Russian

sense.def: the father of your husband or wife
dictionaryExamples: My father-in-law was a banker.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My father-in-law, I'm pretty sure, [will] be able to answer all your questions. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: Fatty foods contain a lot of fat.
dictionaryExamples: Try to cut down on eating fatty foods.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is a greater reliance on fast food and fatty foods. International English Language Testing System; C1; Dari

sense.def: the part at the end of a pipe that controls the flow of water
dictionaryExamples: Turn on/off the faucet.
The faucet in the bathroom sink is leaking.

sense.def: perfect, or without any mistakes
dictionaryExamples: a faultless performance
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Children also need to be taught that parents are not faultless and the best way to teach a child to apologi[z]e is by doing it oneself after having treated the child [unfairly]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: not working correctly or not in perfect condition
dictionaryExamples: faulty brakes
faulty reasoning
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I do believe you should not mislead your readers by giving them faulty information. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: something that you do to help someone
dictionaryExamples: She called up to ask me a favor.
Could you do me a  favor - could you give this to Sean, please?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I need to ask you a favor. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to agree with or approve of a plan or idea
dictionaryExamples: Most people are in favor of reducing traffic in cities.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am more in favor of longer opening hours during the week, and of shorter ones on [the] weekend. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: showing that you like or approve of someone or something, or making you support or approve of someone or something
dictionaryExamples: She made a very favorable impression on us.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would be glad if a favorable answer is given to my request. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: best liked or most enjoyed
dictionaryExamples: "What's your favorite color?" "Green."
My favorite food is pasta.
my favorite band/book/movie
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My favorite place is the Hotel near Olomouc. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Croatian

sense.def: a thing that someone likes best or enjoys most
dictionaryExamples: How smart of you to buy chocolate chip cookies - they're my favorite.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Here in Mendoza there are very good restaurant[s], but one of them is my favorite and it's located in Godoy Cruz, Mendoza. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to send a document using a fax machine
dictionaryExamples: Fax me your reply/Fax your reply to me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will ask one of my classmate[s] to fax me the work you give, and I will try to do it. Preliminary English Test; B1; Malay

sense.def: a strong, unpleasant feeling that you get when you think that something bad, dangerous, or frightening  might happen
dictionaryExamples: her fear of snakes
Shaking/Trembling with fear, she handed over the money to the gunman.
There are fears that the disease will spread to other countries.
Fears for her safety are growing.
The low profit figures simply confirmed my worst fears.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was afraid to eat [it] but after the first bite, I lost my fear. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: because you are worried about something/doing something
dictionaryExamples: I didn't want to move for fear of waking her up.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: No one dared to turn around for fear of being bitterly disappointed. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to be worried or frightened that something bad might happen or might have happened
dictionaryExamples: Police fear (that) the couple may have drowned.
It is feared (that) as many as two hundred passengers may have died in the crash.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Lots of changes which may occur during these next fifty years [might] make us fear that our sons' and grandsons' lives will not be as happy as ours. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to be frightened of something or someone
dictionaryExamples: Most older employees fear unemployment.
What do you fear most?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I've always feared the dark. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to worry that something very bad will happen or that something very bad has happened
dictionaryExamples: When there was no sign of the children, the rescuers feared the worst.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Her parents had been quar[re]lling constantly now for almost half [a] year, and she feared the worst. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: frightened or worried
dictionaryExamples: He was fearful of driving on the icy streets.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My mother is a very fearful person and when I was playing with other children in the sea I could not stand [it] when she interrupted our game all the time with the same words: "Do not do that and do not do this, it is to[o] dangerous." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: not frightened of anything
dictionaryExamples: a fearless fighter
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Yannis knew all about it, but he was fearless and stu[b]born, as people described him, willing to work hard and determined to succeed. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: possible or reasonable and likely to do
dictionaryExamples: a feasible plan
It’s no longer feasible to fund this research.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the context of Singapore, where land is scarce and [the] widening or building of more roads is just not feasible, we have no choice but to choose what is best for everyone. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: a large meal, especially to celebrate something special
dictionaryExamples: Everyone cooked a different dish and we had quite a feast!
a wedding feast
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, they have a feast with a lot of food and wine. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to eat a lot of food and enjoy it very much
dictionaryExamples: We feasted on fried chicken, ice cream, and chocolate cake.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some people think that traveling entails feasting on typical food and buying lots of clothes. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: an act or achievement that shows great skill or strength
dictionaryExamples: The Eiffel Tower is a remarkable feat of engineering.
Getting the house painted was quite a feat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Try as I might, getting good grades was always met more with a sense of mission accomplished - duly noted - than a feat worthy of congratulations. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: used when you want to emphasize that an act or achievement is very difficult
dictionaryExamples: Learning to ski at 60 is no mean feat!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There was an interesting discussion about whether it was harder or easier for them to enter the world of cinema, given their famous names. Both said that it was no mean feat because people were more demanding as [to] their abilities. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: one of the soft, light things that grow from and cover a bird's skin
dictionaryExamples: I found a peacock's feather.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Birds were cleaning their feathers [and singing] morning songs, monkeys were jumping [at] the top of an old tree in the corner of the mon[aste]ry yard. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: a typical quality, or an important part of something
dictionaryExamples: The town's main features are its beautiful mosque and ancient marketplace.
Our latest phone has several new features.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He explained the features of the new product to the rest of his colleagues. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: Someone's features are the parts of their face that you notice when you look at them.
dictionaryExamples: His eyes are his best feature.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They have similar figures, [and] the features of their faces are nearly the same. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a special article in a newspaper or magazine, or a special television program
dictionaryExamples: a double-page feature on global warming
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As a regular reader of the student magazine "Uni," I read with particular interest last week's feature on political thrillers. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to include someone or something as an important part
dictionaryExamples: The film features James Dean as a disaffected teenager.
This week's broadcast features a report on victims of domestic violence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I truly hope that the festival next year will feature more of the plays. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: the second month of the year, after January and before March
dictionaryExamples: the 28th of February/February 28(th)
I was born on the fifth of February/February fifth.
We moved into a new house last February
We are moving into a new house next February.
Building work is expected to start in February.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'll begin on February 21st at 10:00 a.m. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: relating to the central government of some countries
dictionaryExamples: the federal government
Federal law regulates trade with other countries.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The federal government spending is lower compared to [the] USA, which will [be] discussed in the latter part of the report. International English Language Testing System; C1; English

sense.def: a group of organizations, countries, regions, etc. that have joined together to form a larger organization or government
dictionaryExamples: Canada is a federation of provinces and territories.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In Yugoslavia sport[s] was an important factor contributing to the overall stability of the federation. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Slovene

sense.def: annoyed or bored by something that you have experienced for too long
dictionaryExamples: I'm fed up with my job.
He got fed up with all the traveling he had to do.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm sure that the whole world is fed up with Mozart. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: an amount of money that you pay to do something, to use something, or to get a service
dictionaryExamples: legal/late fees
an admission/registration fee

sense.def: extremely weak
dictionaryExamples: She became too feeble to get out of bed.

sense.def: not very good or effective
dictionaryExamples: a feeble argument/excuse

sense.def: to give food to a person, group or animal
dictionaryExamples: I usually feed the neighbor's cat while she's away.

If you feed your dog on cake and cookies, it's not surprising he's so fat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can also ride horses and feed animals like rabbits, birds and hamsters. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: If an animal or a baby feeds, it eats.
dictionaryExamples: The caterpillars feed on cabbage leaves.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the same way, animals killed plants and fed on them. International English Language Testing System; B2; Farsi

sense.def: to supply something such as information to a person or a machine, especially in a regular or continuous way
dictionaryExamples: We fed them false information about our plans.
Nicola fed the pages into the photocopier.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For heaven's sake, the strike lasted for three weeks not three years. [...] They feed you with lies. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: information or opinions about something, such as a new product, that provide an idea of whether it is successful or liked
dictionaryExamples: Have you had any feedback from customers about the product?
positive/negative feedback
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am writing to you to give you feedback about [the] social progra[m]. First Certificate in English; B2; Czech

sense.def: to experience something physical or emotional
dictionaryExamples: "How are you feeling?" "Not too bad, but I've still got a headache."

I'm feeling really happy today!

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like Prague, because it is place where I feel good. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: to have a feeling or idea about something that you have experienced even though it is not true
dictionaryExamples: I feel as if I've known you for ages.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I feel like I've been here for ages. Preliminary English Test; B1; Croatian

sense.def: to have a wish for something, or to want to do something, at a particular moment
dictionaryExamples: I feel like going for a swim.
I feel like a nice cool glass of lemonade.

He was so rude I felt like hitting him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The weather is warm and I feel like swimming. Preliminary English Test; B1; Singhalese

sense.def: to seem to be similar to a type of person, thing, or situation
dictionaryExamples: My feet feel like blocks of ice.

dictionaryExamples: I feel (that) I should be doing more to help her.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The more he got close to this man, the more he felt sure it was Chris, who died in a car crash in April 1972. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to feel sympathy for someone because they are in a difficult situation
dictionaryExamples: I feel so sorry for the children - it must be really hard for them.

sense.def: to feel happy and confident in a place or situation
dictionaryExamples: After a month she felt at home in her new job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I explained: "I was in Manchester for just 10 month[s] and [during] that time the people from there made me feel at home [so] I feel proud to have the accent." Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to touch something, especially with your hands, in order to examine it
dictionaryExamples: I felt his head and it was hot.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I tried to open the heavy door; I could feel the iron bar with my almost frozen fingers. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: If a place, situation, etc., feels different, strange, etc., that is how it seems to you, or that describes your experience of it.
dictionaryExamples: It felt strange to see him again after so long.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It felt strange and yet so wonderful to ski in the summer! First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to be aware of something
dictionaryExamples: I could feel them watching me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I could feel the silence. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to feel that you should do something
dictionaryExamples: He felt compelled to resign from his job.

dictionaryExamples: Seeing all the blood made me feel faint.

sense.def: emotion
dictionaryExamples: a feeling of joy/sadness

dictionaryExamples: You can't hide your feelings from me.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can't explain my feelings. Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish

sense.def: an idea that something is true or exists
dictionaryExamples: I had the strange feeling that we had met before.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I saw the policeman['s] face I got a bad feeling about this man. He d[id]n't look like a cop but he was [dressed] like one, so I decide[d] to stay away from this guy. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: when you feel something physical
dictionaryExamples: I've got this odd feeling in my stomach.
My toes were so cold that I'd lost all feeling in them.

sense.def: an opinion or belief
dictionaryExamples: My feeling is that we had better act quickly or it will be too late.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My feeling is that we shou[l]d simply buy what we want to buy [and] not what we are prompted to buy. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: anger, unhappiness, or lack of trust
dictionaryExamples: I hope you don't have any hard feelings.

sense.def: describes someone who has the same job or interests as you, or is in the same situation as you

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In conclusion, I have to declare that [I] myself and my fellow students will be available to help [with] this short video. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: belonging or relating to women, or to the sex that can produce eggs or have babies
dictionaryExamples: a female athlete/employee
female cats/elephants

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All my female friends at school say that he is [an] attractive young man. Preliminary English Test; B1; Serbian

sense.def: a female animal or person
dictionaryExamples: The kitten was actually a female, not a male.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We all know the problems that [are] cause[d] [by] having animals kept in a zoo: females refuse the males, or they become mad [from] the lack of freedom. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: showing qualities that people generally think are typical of women
dictionaryExamples: a feminine voice
feminine beauty
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When my grandmother was a young women, it was a must for her to wear a dress or at least a skirt and a very feminine blouse. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: a wood, wire or metal structure which divides or goes around an area of land
dictionaryExamples: a garden fence
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I looked around to make sure that no-one saw me and jumped [over] the fence. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: a boat that regularly carries passengers and often vehicles across an area of water

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We are planning to go to the "Red Island", which is just 15 minutes from Rovigno by ferry. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: Fertile land or soil produces a lot of healthy plants.
dictionaryExamples: They settled in the fertile river valleys.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I d[e]cided to go to that city because of the film festival that was going to happen. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: a special day or period when people celebrate something, especially a religious event
dictionaryExamples: a harvest festival
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like to dress up traditional[l]y during festivals. Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil

First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I couldn't figure out what had happened. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a collection of information and documents about someone or something

a film critic
the film industry

sense.def: a film director, especially an independent one who has control over how the film is made
dictionaryExamples: one of the industry's top film-makers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The plot [i]s about a film-maker and his difficulties [in] finish[ing] his last film. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: extremely dirty
dictionaryExamples: Wash your hands, they're filthy!
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: Although the listening area is enormous, it is filthy and there [are] papers everywhere. 
 Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: rude or offensive

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As far as books are concerned, pornography and filthy language is evident everywhere, to lure people to buy these books. International English Language Testing System; C1; Hindi

sense.def: to think or feel a particular way about someone or something

I find living in the city very stressful.
I found her very helpful.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I found it very amusing. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to have or get enough money/time, etc. to do something
dictionaryExamples: Where do you find the money to do all these things?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can even go somewhere with your friends and have fun with them: if you do both things everyone will be happy, you have three months: you can find the time to do everything. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to become aware that you have gone somewhere or done something without intending to
dictionaryExamples: I suddenly found myself making lunch.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The most embar[r]assing moment of my life [was] when, during a school trip to Paris, a friend of mine and I went to the wrong room and found ourselves in front of our teacher who, having had a shower, was looking for his glasses. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: to exist or be present somewhere
dictionaryExamples: Many plant and animal species are found only in the rainforests.
Vitamin C is found in citrus fruit.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: An example might be the [k]oala bear, which could be found almost everywhere in Australia not so long ago. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to judge that someone is guilty or not guilty in a law court
dictionaryExamples: She was found guilty of murder.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To the surprise of everyone in the village, the judge found her guilty but didn't send her to jail because he thought she should take care of Linda, who had no other relatives. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to criticize someone or something, especially without good reasons
dictionaryExamples: She was always finding fault with our work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sometimes I take offence at their trying to find fault with me and I am not allowed to answer back. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to get information about something, or to learn a fact for the first time
dictionaryExamples: How did you find out about the party?

I'll go find out what's going on
                             outside.
We need to find out why he's late.

Too late, she found out that the train had been
                             cancelled.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was at home when I found out that I had lost my cell-phone. Key English Test; A2; Czech

sense.def: well, healthy, or happy
dictionaryExamples: "How are you?" "I'm fine, thanks."
I felt terrible last night but I feel fine this morning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm fine.  Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Somali

sense.def: used to agree with a suggestion, idea, etc.
dictionaryExamples: "Should we meet at 8 o'clock?" "Yes, that's fine."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you want to me[e]t me on Monday, that's fine. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: good or good enough
dictionaryExamples: "Is this soup hot enough?" "Yes, it's fine."

sense.def: sunny and not raining
dictionaryExamples: It should be a fine day tomorrow.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [The] weather is fine. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: excellent or much better than average
dictionaryExamples: a fine musician/artist
There is a fine view of the river from the balcony.
This building is the finest example of its type.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There [we] will be served a fine dinner. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: a very small difference between two things that may seem different
dictionaryExamples: There's a fine line between courage and foolishness.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It took me 6 months to reali[z]e that there is a fine line between telling off and psychological abuse. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Czech

sense.def: thin or made of very small pieces
dictionaryExamples: fine, brown hair
fine sand
