sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They got their hands on some anthrax bacteria, grew them in petri dishes and with all her knowledge in biology managed to make anthrax spores. Her friends ground the clumps of spores into fine particles. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: an amount of money that you must pay for breaking a rule or law
dictionaryExamples: She had to pay a fine.
a parking fine
The maximum penalty is a $1000 fine.
If found guilty, he faces  a heavy fine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She was made to pay a fine and she wasn't sent to prison. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to charge someone an amount of money as a punishment for not obeying a rule or law
dictionaryExamples: Drivers who break the speed limit can expect to be fined heavily.
They fined him $100 for speeding on the highway.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Besides, you can be fined by the police. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: very well or without any problems
dictionaryExamples: "How did your exam go?" "It went fine, I think."
The car was working fine yesterday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The couple was great and everything went fine. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: into small pieces
dictionaryExamples: Finely chop the onion.

sense.def: one of the long, thin parts of the hand that hold things, including the thumb
dictionaryExamples: He noticed her long delicate fingers.
I cut my finger chopping vegetables last night.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then my mother brought the cake and while she was lighting the candles she burn[ed] her finger. Key English Test; A2; Farsi

blocks.phrase: keep your fingers crossed/cross your fingers

sense.def: to hope that things will happen in the way that you want them to, and to put a finger over the one next to it as a sign of that hope
dictionaryExamples: Let's keep our fingers crossed that she gets the job.
We're crossing our fingers and hoping that the weather stays fine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Wish me luck, Winnie," she sighed "keep your fingers crossed, please." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to understand exactly why a situation is the way it is
dictionaryExamples: Something was wrong, but I couldn't put my finger on it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Something sinister about the picture, he felt, but he couldn't put his finger on what made him [think this]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

blocks.phrase: have/keep your finger on the pulse

sense.def: to be/stay familiar with the most recent changes or improvements
dictionaryExamples: The situation changes daily, so you've got to keep your finger on the pulse.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It wouldn't be clever to hire people who are completely ignora[nt] about music and they must constantly keep their finger on the pulse of [the] music industry. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: the hard part that covers and protects the top of the end of your finger
dictionaryExamples: dirty/long fingernails
She had bright red fingernails.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Half way through dinner we had discussed almost everything about him: his lips, fingernails, how he would look in swim [trunks] how he would dance, etc. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to complete something, or come to the end of an activity
dictionaryExamples: I'll call you when I've finished my homework.
Please place your questionnaire in the box when you've finished.
She finished the concert with a song from her first album.
Have you finished reading that magazine?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have finished my course. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: to end
dictionaryExamples: The meeting should finish around four o'clock.
The play finishes with a song.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will finish work at five o'clock. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: to eat, drink or use something completely so that none remains
dictionaryExamples: He finished his coffee and left.
We finished the pie last night.

blocks.phrasalVerb: finish off sth or finish sth off

sense.def: to complete the last part of something that you are doing
dictionaryExamples: I want to finish off this essay before I go to bed.

sense.def: the end of a race, or the last part of something
dictionaryExamples: a close finish
They replayed the finish in slow motion.
I enjoyed the film from start to finish.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We [had] a race and I [came] second [at] the finish. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: having a limit or end
dictionaryExamples: We only have a finite amount of time to complete this task.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last but not least, the problem of pollution.  It is recognized as an increased hazard in modern society and if we take into account that the air we breathe is finite, we should do our best to restrict the main culprits such as cars, factories, insecticides and so on. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: heat, light, and flames that are produced when something burns
dictionaryExamples: The library was badly damaged in the fire.
It is thought that the fire was started deliberately.
It took the firefighters three hours to put out the fire.
How many historic buildings are damaged by fire each year?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Yesterday I bought very cool clothes. [...] I bought them because yesterday all my shoes and T-shirts were burned [in] a fire. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: to start burning
dictionaryExamples: The car crashed and caught fire.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One of the new machines that I had brought from Germany had caught fire. Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil

sense.def: If something is on fire, it is burning when it should not be.
dictionaryExamples: If your home was on fire and you could save only one thing, what would it be?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A lot of bu[i]ldings were on fire. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a small controlled fire that is used for heating or cooking
dictionaryExamples: It's very cold in here - should I light a fire?
We built a fire on the beach.
We put up our tents and made a small fire.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the evenings we sat down [o]n the grass round a fire and talked to each other. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: the shooting of guns and other weapons
dictionaryExamples: The soldiers opened fire.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suddenly, one of the thieves opened fire. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to be criticized
dictionaryExamples: The government has come under fire for closing the hospital.

blocks.phrase: set fire to sth; set sth on fire

sense.def: to make something start burning, usually to cause damage
dictionaryExamples: Enemy troops set fire to the village.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At this point nothing made sense anymore, so I just watched while Jake set the car on fire. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to be involved in an activity that could be dangerous
dictionaryExamples: We're playing with fire if we continue with genetic modification of our food.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Stop playing with fire or World War 3 might come in [the] shape of a nuclear war. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: to cause a weapon to shoot bullets, arrows or missiles
dictionaryExamples: He fired his gun into the air.
He fired three shots.
Someone started firing at us.
Without warning he started firing into the crowd.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Martins found Lime on an iron staircase and fired a last shot, killing Lime. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: to tell someone they must leave their job
dictionaryExamples: She was fired after she was caught stealing from her employer.
He was fired from his last job for poor performance.
She has just been fired as editor of the newspaper.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last month I was fired from my job in a bank. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to make someone very excited or interested in something
dictionaryExamples: His paintings really fired my imagination.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The newspaper article on education that I read really fired my imagination and urged me to think about the points raised. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: an organization that is in charge of preventing and stopping unwanted fires
dictionaryExamples: Someone called the fire department, and the blaze was quickly put out.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The first thing I've done was call the fire department but they told me the it would take some time because they had another building on fire in another part of town. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a person whose job is to stop fires from burning
dictionaryExamples: My cousin Mark is a firefighter.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We could see firefighters and ambulances coming from all over the premises! First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: a space in the wall of a room where you can have a fire, or the structure around this space
dictionaryExamples: There was a large fireplace in the living room.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They were sitting in front of the fireplace, in a tiny cottage. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: the building where fire engines are kept and firefighters wait for emergencies
dictionaryExamples: We visited our local fire station.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I only saw M[r]. Bean from my class[room] window - they were filming him running to the fire station. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: a small object that explodes to produce a loud noise and bright colors, often used to celebrate special events
dictionaryExamples: a fireworks display

When it gets dark they'll
                      set off the fireworks.
What time do the fireworks start?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have spent three days [at] Disneyland, watching fireworks every night. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: not soft, but not completely hard
dictionaryExamples: A firm mattress is better for your back.

sense.def: certain or fixed and not likely to change
dictionaryExamples: We don't have any firm plans for the weekend yet.
I'm a firm believer in equal rights.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is my firm belief that I would use all the experience I have. First Certificate in English; B2; Czech

sense.def: strict and making certain that people do what you want
dictionaryExamples: You've got to be firm with children.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Being an officer, my father was rather firm with my sister and me. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: strong and tight
dictionaryExamples: a firm handshake/grip
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The teacher, Miss Parchman, keeping a firm grip on his hand, took Peter outside of the classroom in order to get him calm. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a company or business
dictionaryExamples: He works for a law firm called Neil and Vigliano.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The only thing I could remember was that the meeting was set up at 9 a.m. and that a law firm in Zurich was looking for a secretary. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: in a way that is certain or fixed
dictionaryExamples: I firmly believe that we must take action on this.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I firmly believe that some of the things you mentioned are wrong. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: strongly; in a way that will not become loose
dictionaryExamples: Make sure the rope is firmly attached before attempting to climb down it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Slowly but firmly I grab[b]ed the door handle, took another quick glance in the room, and turned it. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: coming before all others
dictionaryExamples: This is my first trip to New York.
Karen was the first person to arrive.
We met for the first time yesterday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Near the city there is [the] first championship golf course in Slovakia. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: most important, top
dictionaryExamples: Sheila won first prize in the photo competition.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was good because my cousin played and won the first prize. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: at the start of a situation
dictionaryExamples: Why did you invite her in the first place?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the first place, you were unknown people for me, but now you are my special foreign friends. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: before everything or everyone else
dictionaryExamples: I can come out tonight, but I've got to do my homework first.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have to go to [the] dentist first! Key English Test; A2; Thai

sense.def: before anything else
dictionaryExamples: First of all, I’d like to ask you a few questions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Pat: first of all, thanks for your invitation. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: for the first time
dictionaryExamples: When did you first meet each other?
I first heard the song on the radio.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I first heard of it [o]n the radio and then I saw a leaflet about it. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: used to introduce the first idea, reason, etc., in a series
dictionaryExamples: First, I want to thank my parents.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First we all met in "Linda's cafe" and brought our bikes with us, then we start[ed] our trip to Texas. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: at the beginning of a situation or period of time
dictionaryExamples: At first I thought she was unfriendly, but actually she's just shy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At first, when I arrived I was very nervous because I didn't know anyone, but then a girl started talking to me and I felt better. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: more than anything else
dictionaryExamples: In spite of being elected to office, she remains first and foremost a writer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First and foremost it is my longing to help others with what they cannot do for themselves. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: when you first see or hear about something or someone
dictionaryExamples: It may, at first sight, seem a surprising choice.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I must admit that, at first sight, I did not feel like reading it, but later I made up my mind and decided to accept your invitation. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to be the most important person or thing
dictionaryExamples: Her career always comes first.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They do not take the time to sit down and enjoy being with their family. The work comes first, and the family next. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: to consider someone or something to be the most important thing
dictionaryExamples: Most couples put their children first.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand, we forget about our personality and the worth that we have as individuals; we put our wishes first, [rather] than what we really need in life. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: the first person or thing to do or be something, or the first person or thing mentioned
dictionaryExamples: Tonight sees the first of three documentaries about cancer.
She was one of the first to arrive.
He is the first to admit that much of his success is due to his good looks.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I prefer the first because it's an exciting story of a cat that escapes from a dangerous house lived [in] by an aggressive dog. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to be something that has never happened before
dictionaryExamples: Winning the state championship was a first for out school.

sense.def: the floor of a building that is at the same level as the ground outside
dictionaryExamples: She works on the first floor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My bedroom is on the first floor. Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish

sense.def: on the first floor
dictionaryExamples: a first-floor apartment/office/classroom

sense.def: the language that someone learns to speak first
dictionaryExamples: Madeleine's first language is French, but she also speaks English fluently.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Originally I come from Germany and therefore my first language is German. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: used to refer to the first thing in a list
dictionaryExamples: There are two very good reasons why we can't do it. Firstly, we don't have enough money, and secondly, we don't have enough time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think it [would] suit us, firstly because it is good work experience, [and] secondly [because] we can get discounts on books and CDs. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: the personal name that was given to you when you were born and that is not your family's name
dictionaryExamples: It can be rude to call someone by their first name if they are much older or more important than you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After that he asked the students to introduce themselves, and he easily learned the first name[s] of the student[s] and addressed them [by] their first name except me and it really annoyed me. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: the form of a verb or pronoun that is used when people are speaking or writing about themselves. For example, "I" and "we" are first person pronouns.
dictionaryExamples: Autobiographies are written in the first person.

sense.def: an animal that lives only in water and swims using its tail and fins
dictionaryExamples: Several large fish live in the pond.
Sanjay caught the biggest fish I've ever seen.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We are going to go to an even larger (no, the largest) river to catch fish next week!! Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: fish eaten as food
dictionaryExamples: fried fish
I don't eat fish or meat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Usually in Spain every day the people eat potatoes and salads with fish or meat. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Spanish

sense.def: to try to catch fish
dictionaryExamples: They're fishing for tuna.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the countryside the air is pure and you can fish in lakes or walk in fields. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: someone who catches fish as a job or as a hobby
dictionaryExamples: Local fishermen are finding it difficult to make a living.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His father was a fisherman and he died working just a few days before he was born, so the child had never met him. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: the sport or job of catching fish
dictionaryExamples: My dad loves to go fishing.
salmon fishing
Fishing is still their main source of income.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We can go fishing or hunting. Key English Test; A2; Greek

sense.def: a hand closed into a ball with the fingers and thumb curled tightly together
dictionaryExamples: He banged his fist down angrily on the table.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He slammed his fists against the door and yelled out several times but to no response. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: to be the right size or shape for someone or something
dictionaryExamples: That jacket fits you perfectly.
These jeans don't fit me any more.
I can't find a lid to fit this jar.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I never go shopping for clothes, I only go shopping like once a year to buy shoes when the ones I have don't fit me. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: If people or things fit somewhere, or if you can fit them somewhere, that place is big enough for them.
dictionaryExamples: How many people can you fit in your car?
This radio is small enough to fit into my pocket.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The desk has to be very small and has to fit into the corner, because there is not much space left in my bedroom. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to be the same as or like something
dictionaryExamples: She seems to fit the description.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The ac[c]ommodation[s] I [had] during the trip didn't fit the description in the advertisement and neither did the restaurants or the cultural activit[ie]s. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: to be suitable for something
dictionaryExamples: The job fits him well.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You ought to put on a formal dress or suit to fit the atmosphere. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: to feel that you belong to a particular group and are accepted by them
dictionaryExamples: He doesn't fit in with the other  pupils in his class.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I do not think it is a good idea to advertise the club in a big way, it would not be very s[e]ri[o]us of us.  We could tell only the people that we think could fit in. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: If one thing fits in with another thing, it belongs with them or they are suitable for each other.
dictionaryExamples:
It's a very nice sofa but it doesn't fit in with the rest of
                             the furniture.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nevertheless, there was something that wouldn't fit in with what Rollo would hear from Harry's friends. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: If  something fits in with a situation, idea, method, etc., it is suitable and works successfully as part of it.
dictionaryExamples: Changing location fits in with their plans to expand the business.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In conclusion, I think your wedding day should be about you and your partner and the wedding celebrations should fit in with your combined ideas and cultures and wants to make it a memorable occasion for you and not to satisfy other people. International English Language Testing System; C1; Afrikaans

sense.def: healthy and strong, especially as a result of exercise
dictionaryExamples: I joined a gym to get fit.
I jog to keep fit.
You need to be very fit to go mountain climbing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many of people in my country try to be fit and every day for breakfast eat yo[g]urt with flakes and fruits. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish

sense.def: of a good enough quality or suitable type for a particular purpose
dictionaryExamples: He isn't fit to be treasurer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It has undergone restoration recently and is now fit to serve as a perfect example of [a] model and modern British college library. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: believe to be what is good, correct, or necessary
dictionaryExamples: You can leave it here or take it home with you, whichever you see fit.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am, therefore, expressing my willingness, through this letter, to participate in this endeavor in whatever way you may see fit. International English Language Testing System; C2; Tagalog

sense.def: the condition of being physically strong and healthy
dictionaryExamples: I'm trying to improve my physical fitness by riding my bike to work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I specially like fitness lessons. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: the number 5
dictionaryExamples: Five, four, three, two, one, blast-off!
I work five days a week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will finish work at five o'clock. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: to repair something
dictionaryExamples: They couldn't fix my old computer, so I bought a new one.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One day while he was wo[r]king in his office, he received a call from a client that told him to fix some computers in Spain, Rafael accepted. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to arrange or put in place
dictionaryExamples: I need to fix my hair.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Secondly the women witch is going to get maried wears a very big whit dress and her best friend help her to fix her hair Preliminary English Test; B1; Greek

sense.def: to prepare a drink or meal
dictionaryExamples: I'll fix you a sandwich.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: W[o]ken up early by the birds and sunshine we headed downstairs to unpack and fix breakfast. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to decide a certain and exact date, time, or place
dictionaryExamples: Should we fix a time for our next meeting?
They haven't fixed a date for the wedding yet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you are busy at that time, you can call them to fix a new date. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to fasten something in position so that it cannot move
dictionaryExamples: We fixed the bookcase to the wall.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, I have no problem park[ing] my vehicle, [as it] can be fixed to any tree or gate. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: in a difficult situation that causes you trouble or problems
dictionaryExamples: He’s in a fix and needs our help.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She felt happy when I was down in the dumps or in a fix and kept on being jealous of me concerning trivial matters. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

blocks.phrasalVerb: fix up sth or fix sth up

sense.def: to repair of change something so it can be used or looks better
dictionaryExamples: She's almost finished fixing up her new apartment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But you can solve this problem in an easy way [by] just learning to fix up your bicycle, or taking it to the nearest repairing cent[er]. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: arranged or decided already and not able to be changed
dictionaryExamples: a fixed price
fixed interest rates
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Usually you have a fixed time to listen [to] live music, but what if you are not able to go to the concert? First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: If your eyes are fixed on something, you are looking at it continuously.
dictionaryExamples: a fixed stare
I kept my eyes fixed on his face.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My eyes were fixed on those words which seemed to be dancing before me almost as if laughing at me. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a piece of cloth with a special design and colors, that  is the symbol of a country or a group, or has a particular meaning
dictionaryExamples: the Brazilian flag
Flags of all twenty-seven countries are flying outside the building.
Colorful flags decorated the hall.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And about my present from the USA: I really would like to have an authentic American flag, to decorate my bedroom ceiling. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: a natural ability to do something well
dictionaryExamples: She has a flair for languages.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She's an artist with a flair for promotion. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: when you do something in an exciting and interesting way
dictionaryExamples: He played with great imagination and flair.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If I must describe the service I should say that it is superb: the gentle waiters serve with flair as if it was a culinary cabaret. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: hot, bright, burning gas produced by something on fire
dictionaryExamples: The flames grew larger as the fire spread.
When the fire engine arrived the house was already in flames.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We were standing by the window and the flames were [getting] nearer and nearer. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to suddenly start burning
dictionaryExamples: The car plunged down a hill and burst into flames.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When we turned it on, it burst into flames and before we could exti[n]guish it, the fire destroyed my desk. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to shine brightly and suddenly, or to make something shine in this way
dictionaryExamples: Stop flashing that light in my eyes!
The lightning flashed and distant thunder rolled.
You'd better slow down, that car was flashing (its lights) at you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As they were driving back, a light flashed, a crash sounded, then screams. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to appear for a short time, or to make something appear for a short time
dictionaryExamples: An error message flashed on the screen.

sense.def: to move or happen quickly
dictionaryExamples: A fire engine flashed by.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But one day an idea flashed through her mind. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: a sudden bright light
dictionaryExamples: The bomb exploded in a flash of yellow light.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At the same moment, that piece of unknown stuff sent towards me a flash of very bright light! First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: a piece of camera equipment that produces a bright light when you take a photograph in a dark place
dictionaryExamples: Flash photography is not permitted anywhere in the museum.

sense.def: immediately, or very quickly
dictionaryExamples: I'll be back in a flash.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He took it and, in a flash, he came up to the surface. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: when you suddenly remember something that happened in the past, often something bad
dictionaryExamples: She suffered from flashbacks for years after the accident.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Margaret started to remember, yes; a sudden flashback brought her to the twenties, when she was still her mamma's little girl, all innocence and curls. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: part of a film or book that goes back in time to something that happened before the main story began
dictionaryExamples: There are several flashbacks to the character's childhood.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Another way of increasing the reader's interest is the par[al]lelism of both stories and the flashbacks she is always giving us to explain Olivia's experiences. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: a small electric light that you hold in your hand
dictionaryExamples: He lit the way with his flashlight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was going to get a flashlight in my room when I heard a strange noise. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: level and smooth, with no high, raised, or round parts
dictionaryExamples: An ice rink needs to be completely flat.
Roll out the pastry on a flat surface.
Much of the countryside in East Anglia is very flat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The countryside is very flat and for this kind of holiday it's really perfect!! Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: Flat shoes do not raise your feet far from the ground.
dictionaryExamples: Wear flat shoes - you'll be on your feet all day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In your last letter you wanted me to tell you about clothes. Well, as you know I'm tall so I always wear flat shoes in light colors like white, light green and blue. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: If a tire is flat, it does not contain enough air.
dictionaryExamples: When I got to the car, I discovered I had a flat tire.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the evening I got a flat tire, and because of this I got late to the show, when I got to my place, it was used (it cost a lot) and they took me to the cheapest seats, where I couldn't see a thing. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: If a drink is flat, it does not contain enough bubbles of gas.
dictionaryExamples: If you don’t put the top back on the soda bottle, it will go flat.

sense.def: in a level position, often against another surface
dictionaryExamples: Lay the cloth flat across the table.

sense.def: to fall over so that your face hits the ground, often in an embarrassing way
dictionaryExamples: I stepped on the ice and fell flat on my face.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can guess what happened next - I fell flat on my face right in the mud and I have never felt more embarrassed in my life! First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: If an event or joke falls flat, it fails to have the effect that you wanted, such as making people laugh.
dictionaryExamples: All the jokes in his speech fell flat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The cultural visits fell flat [in comparison] to their expectations, although the sightseeing tour of Willstown was, as the students said, "fascinating." Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to become flat or to make something become flat
dictionaryExamples: Roll out the dough into balls and flatten them slightly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Another thing they accomplished was to stop people cutting [down] trees because they wanted to flatten [the] land. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: the way a food or drink tastes, or a particular taste itself
dictionaryExamples: Add a little salt to bring out the flavor of the herbs.
My fish was delicious but Juan's beef had almost no flavor.
We sell 32 different flavors of ice cream.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You should try to offer a wider variety of flavors, instead of just coffee, chocolate and vanilla. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a particular quality or style that something has
dictionaryExamples: London has a very international flavor.

sense.def: a mistake or bad characteristic that stops someone or something from being perfect
dictionaryExamples: There's a flaw in your reasoning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, there were some minor flaws which I would like to give my view on. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: not perfect, or containing mistakes
dictionaryExamples: Diamonds are still valuable, even when they are flawed.
His argument is deeply flawed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some people see society as it stands today as inherently flawed, an amorphous group of people who follow and worship anyone that gives them pleasure and empty dreams of perfection.  Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: with no mistakes or bad characteristics
dictionaryExamples: a flawless complexion
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All in all, it is a classic comedy with memorable dialog[ue] and flawless performances. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to leave a place quickly because you are in danger or are afraid
dictionaryExamples: Police think the suspect has now fled the country.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course most people on those boats were fleeing their country for religious or political reasons but I would have left Europe for the spirit of adventure. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: a group of ships, or all of the ships in a country's navy
dictionaryExamples: The entire naval fleet was used for the operation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The Spartans order the people of Athens to destroy their city walls and most of their remaining fleet. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a group of vehicles that are owned and controlled by one person or organization
dictionaryExamples: a fleet of aircraft/cars
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In a simplified scenario one can consider when one has a fleet of cars, some manual and other automatic, and a pool of drivers who can only drive one type of car. International English Language Testing System; C1; Arabic

sense.def: the soft part of a person's or animal's body between the skin and bones
dictionaryExamples: Large thorns dug into my flesh.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It smelled of rotting flesh. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: a member of your family
dictionaryExamples: I can't hate him - he's my own flesh and blood.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand, another problem old people have to face is a feeling of [not] being useful to society and what proves this is that they are put into old people's homes even by their own flesh and blood. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: the ability to change or be changed easily according to the situation
dictionaryExamples: The advantage of this system is its flexibility.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Further personal strengths are good communication skills, [being a] good team player and flexibility. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: able to change or be changed easily according to the situation
dictionaryExamples: My schedule is quite flexible - I could arrange to meet with you any day next week.
I'd like a job with more flexible working hours.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the advertis[e]ment it is said that you will have a lot of spare time but actually, you have flexible working hours and you never know whether you will have free time. First Certificate in English; B2; Bulgarian

sense.def: able to bend or to be bent easily
dictionaryExamples: The cover is made of flexible plastic.
Dancers and gymnasts need to be very flexible.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Another physical [requirement] is a flexible body. Flexibility and agility will be crucial factor[s] [in] whether you will succeed or not.Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a journey through air or space  in an aircraft or other vehicle
dictionaryExamples: I'll never forget my first flight.
How was your flight?
All flights to New York today are delayed because of bad weather.
My flight was cancelled/delayed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to rest because the flight will be very boring. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a set of stairs connecting one floor to another in a building
dictionaryExamples: The elevator was broken so we had to climb six flights of stairs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He descended a long flight of stairs and reached a door. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to stay on the surface of a liquid and not sink, or to make something do this
dictionaryExamples: Leaves were floating on the surface.
We spent a lazy afternoon floating along/down the river.
He tossed the bottle into the waves and watched it float out to sea.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally we were floating on the sea, admiring the famous bay. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to stay in the air, or move gently through the air
dictionaryExamples: Fluffy white clouds were floating across the sky.
The sound of piano-playing floated out through the open window.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suddenly, I saw a "thing" floating by the window, making noises and  like nothing human. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: If a place floods or is flooded, it becomes covered in water.
dictionaryExamples: The town was flooded when the river overflowed its banks.
Our washing machine broke down yesterday and flooded the kitchen.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The city was flooded and too many people were dead. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to fill or enter a place in large numbers or amounts
dictionaryExamples: She drew back the curtains and the sunlight came flooding in.
Shoppers flooded into the store on the first morning of the sale.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The Square is flooded with local merchants selling local food,  folkloric clothing, and local wines. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to receive so many messages, phone calls, etc., that you cannot deal with them
dictionaryExamples: We were flooded with calls from worried parents.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Soon he was being hired again and once word spread that the musician had returned, he was flooded with bookings. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a large amount of water covering an area that is usually dry
dictionaryExamples: After the flood it took weeks for the water level to go down.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was windy and raining with lots of floods. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: a large number or amount of things or people that arrive at the same time
dictionaryExamples: a flood of letters/calls
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The sea of familiar faces brought a flood of memories rushing back. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: a surface that you walk on inside a building
dictionaryExamples: a wood/tile floor
The bathroom floor needs cleaning.
The children sat playing on the floor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Lily gave me a small toy cat. It can walk on the floor. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: a particular level of a building
dictionaryExamples: This building has five floors.
Take the elevator to the 51st floor.
We live on the third floor.
a ground floor/first-floor apartment
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The new art class is on Tuesday on the first floor with Mrs. Keller. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: an area where a particular activity happens
dictionaryExamples: a dance floor
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It has got a very big dance floor with a skil[l]ful jazz band. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: soft and loose or hanging down loosely
dictionaryExamples: a floppy hat
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That puppy was the cutest thing: [a] tiny body, with floppy ears, a curious wet nose that wanted to sniff everything on its way, and huge cheerful eyes. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: powder made from grain, especially wheat, used for making bread, cakes, pasta, pastry, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Add the flour to the eggs and milk.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He told the family that it was arseni[c] in the flour. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to grow or develop well
dictionaryExamples: The company soon began to flourish under his expert management.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If parents try to understand why their children act the way they do and treat them with love and affection, then teenagers will flourish like flowers in the spring sunshine! Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: If something such as a liquid flows, it moves somewhere in a smooth, continuous way.
dictionaryExamples: The  river flows from the Andes into the Pacific Ocean.
With fewer cars on the roads, traffic is flowing more smoothly than usual.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Stockholm is the capital of Sweden and it is situated at the point where Norrstrom the outlet of Milowne flows out into the Baltic. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: when something flows in one direction
dictionaryExamples: the flow of a river
the traffic flow
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So, a possible solution is to build more roads and optimally design the roads and their subways, to make the flow of cars on [the] road quicker. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: to do or accept what other people are doing because it is the easiest thing to do
dictionaryExamples: Just relax and go with the flow!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At this stage of her progress towards knowing herself better she has accepted that life is a mu[dd]le and that to a certain extent one has to go with the flow. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: the attractive, colored part of a plant where the seeds grow
dictionaryExamples: wild flowers
to pick/cut flowers
a bunch of flowers
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You know I like flowers a lot. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: an infectious illness which is like a very bad cold, but which causes a fever
dictionaryExamples: a flu virus
I had the flu last week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope you're fine and you don't have the flu any more. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to keep changing, especially in level or amount
dictionaryExamples: Oil prices have fluctuated wildly in recent weeks.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: During that period transportation by pipeline an road was slightly increasing while transportation by rail was fluctuating. International English Language Testing System; C2; Lithuanian

sense.def: when someone is fluent in a language
dictionaryExamples:
One of the requirements of the job is fluency in two or more
                         African languages.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So it is of the utmost importance for me to go to England in [the] very near future in order to improve my fluency in English. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: able to use a language naturally without stopping or making mistakes
dictionaryExamples: She's fluent in French.
He's a fluent Russian speaker.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am fluent in French and English. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: produced or done in a smooth, natural style
dictionaryExamples: He speaks fluent Chinese.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I speak fluent English and German. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: in a way that is fluent
dictionaryExamples: I'd like to speak English fluently.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can speak both English and Japanese fluently. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: a liquid
dictionaryExamples: Drink plenty of fluids.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Healthy eating habits consist of lots of fruit and vegetables, calcium-rich products such as milk or cheese and plenty of fluid[s]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swiss German

sense.def: smooth and continuous with a flowing or changing quality
dictionaryExamples: a dancer’s fluid movements
The situation remains fluid – we offered her the job, but she hasn’t responded yet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The third-person narration is fluid and delicate and enables us to gradually discover the characters' personalities and their reactions to the situations they are involved in. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: a musical instrument in the shape of a tube that is held out to the side and played by blowing across a hole at one end
dictionaryExamples: Ellen started learning the flute at the age of 12.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now I know [the] history of [the] violin, flute, cello, viola, oboe, etc. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: to travel through the air  in an aircraft
dictionaryExamples: I'm flying to Mumbai tomorrow.
We fly out of Kennedy, but fly back into Newark.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm flying to Poland with my daughter. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish

sense.def: When a bird, insect or aircraft flies, it moves through the air.
dictionaryExamples: The plane was flying at 5000 feet.
The poor bird couldn't fly because it had a broken wing.
As soon as it saw us, the bird flew away/off.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The birds fly [i]n the sky. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Mandarin

sense.def: to control an aircraft or other vehicle in air or space
dictionaryExamples: She learned to fly at the age of 18.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Louise, you are the only one who can fly this spaceship now. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: with a very high score or with great success
dictionaryExamples: He passed the exam with flying colors.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thr[o]u[gh] this, he was able to get his college degree and graduated with flying colors. International English Language Testing System; C1; Tagalog

sense.def: If time flies, it passes very quickly.
dictionaryExamples: There was plenty to do, and the time flew.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But you have to enjoy it because time flies, and you will be old before you know it! Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to take or send people or goods somewhere by aircraft
dictionaryExamples: She was flown to the hospital by helicopter.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All supplies are flown in daily from Paris in order to ensure the highest quality available. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to be the opposite of what is usual or accepted
dictionaryExamples: These recommendations fly in the face of previous advice on safe limits of consumption.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But when we have a look outside our wonderful world, we can easily see that this argument flies in the face of the facts. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: a small insect with two wings
dictionaryExamples: There were a lot of flies around.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the afternoon we were just lying like dead flies on our beds.  First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: thick cloud just above the ground or water that makes it difficult to see
dictionaryExamples: Thick/Heavy fog has made driving conditions dangerous.
It took several hours for the fog to clear/lift.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Imagine, in the morning there was fog, and it was a cold day. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: with fog
dictionaryExamples: a foggy day
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was a foggy afternoon and I was at home. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: If you fold paper, cloth, etc., you bend it so that one part of it lies flat on top of another part.
dictionaryExamples: I folded the letter in half and put it in an envelope.
Will you help me to fold up the sheets?
He had a neatly folded handkerchief in his jacket pocket.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And the next morning, I was here again to help them folding their stuff. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a piece of plastic or thick paper folded down the middle and used to hold loose papers
dictionaryExamples: I keep all my bank statements in this folder.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think I forgot my folder in your house. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a place on a computer where particular files are kept
dictionaryExamples: I made a new folder on the C drive.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Computers are very important because we work with them, [and] we keep our secret folders and files in [them]. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: music written and played in a traditional style
dictionaryExamples: There are several venues for folk and jazz in the city.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can sing most kinds of songs, such as pop music, folk. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: the traditional style of art, dancing, etc. among a particular group of people
dictionaryExamples: She's studied the folk art of the region.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There  are a lot of folk stories in Lithuania, [and] I would like to tell you one of them. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: your parents
dictionaryExamples: I'm going home to see my folks next weekend.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please say hello to your folks for me, and write me! First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: people, especially those of a particular group or type
dictionaryExamples: Some folks don't like SUVs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Cathy How are you? Everything all right? How [are] John and Richard?  I miss you folks! First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to move behind someone or something and go where they go
dictionaryExamples: A dog followed us home.
She followed me into the kitchen.
He had the feeling he was being followed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'll wait for you in the central square and you [can] follow me. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: to travel along a street, path, road, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Follow the main road down to the traffic light.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can get to my house by following the road [from] the corner which is next to the playground. Key English Test; A2; Greek

sense.def: to happen or come after something
dictionaryExamples: There was a bang, followed by a cloud of smoke.
The meal consisted of smoked salmon, followed by Welsh lamb.
We were not prepared for the events that followed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the first lesson we started with some games, followed by work activities, like role plays and presentations. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to do what someone or something says you should do
dictionaryExamples: Follow the instructions on the back of the package carefully.
I decided to follow her advice and go to bed early.
If you follow the signs, you won't get lost.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think I should follow her advice, shouldn't I? Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to understand something
dictionaryExamples: Could you repeat that? I didn't quite follow what you said.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is very hard to follow the lesson because I can'[t] concentrate on the vocabulary. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: used to introduce a list or description
dictionaryExamples: The main reasons are as follows.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The errors made in the newspaper are as follows. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to be interested in an event or activity and watch its progress
dictionaryExamples: I followed the trial closely.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was happy to know you follow our national news. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: used to say that if one thing is true, another thing will also be true
dictionaryExamples: He's big, but it doesn't follow that he's strong.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It follows that they too do not have enough time. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to copy someone's behavior or ideas
dictionaryExamples: You should follow Meg's example and tidy your room.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thus they are encouraged to follow their example and change their character forever. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to do the same things in your life as someone else did, especially a member of your family
dictionaryExamples: He followed in his father's footsteps and became an actor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Her step-granddaughter gets fascinated with Olivia's story and this fascination draws her to India to follow in her footsteps. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: to do the same as someone else has just done
dictionaryExamples: If other shops lower their prices, we will have to follow suit.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Bitten by a insurmountable curiosity she goes to India to [find out] about her and she even follows suit: she ends up [in] the Himalay[a]s driven by a strong desire to know more. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

blocks.phrasalVerb: follow up sth or follow sth up

sense.def: to discover more about a situation or take further action in connection with it
dictionaryExamples: I follow up aerobic exercise with some weight lifting.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last year I started to take a lot of black and white photos and I wanted to follow up the process so I bought an enlarger with all the equipment to [go with] it.  First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: someone who supports or believes in a particular person or set of ideas
dictionaryExamples: The newly elected governor appeared overcome with emotion as he thanked his followers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Having been a devoted follower of the GDR's political system and having spent the collaps[e] of this very system in a coma in hospital, once she wakes up, Christane has to be sheltered from the new developments. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: after or as a result of
dictionaryExamples: Following the dinner, there will be a dance.
He died on October 23rd, following several years of illness.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Following the course in England, I worked in an office that sells computer programs and games as a secretary to earn money and with the help of this job, I gained experience in office work. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: the next day/morning, etc.
dictionaryExamples: We met again the following afternoon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I could give it back to you the following day. Preliminary English Test; B1; Czech

sense.def: what comes next, often used to introduce a list, report, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The following is an extract from her diary.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Regarding your questions, the following are my answers. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: something that people and animals eat, or plants absorb, to keep them alive
dictionaryExamples: baby food
Thai food
to cook/prepare food
There was lots of food at the party.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'd like to eat Italian food, maybe lasagne. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: a stupid person
dictionaryExamples: I was a fool to trust him.
I felt like a complete fool.
He's a fool if he thinks she's interested.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I wonder if I'm a fool because in spite of my economic problems I want to join the best tennis club in the town, but I love tennis. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to make someone look stupid intentionally
dictionaryExamples: She was always trying to make a fool out of me in front of my friends.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He thought I had tried to make a fool of him but no, I was really desperate to get him as my boyfriend. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: to behave in a silly or embarrassing way
dictionaryExamples: I got very excited  and made a fool of myself.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had to leave that shop in full embarrassment and I also made a fool of myself. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: to trick someone
dictionaryExamples: Don't be fooled by his appearance.
She said she was doing it to help me but I wasn't fooled.
Tim was fooled into believing that he'd won a lot of money.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't like to be fooled.  First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: stupid and not wise
dictionaryExamples: It would be foolish to pay more.
I thought I might look foolish if I refused.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She looked foolish because of the mistakes she [had] made. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: in a foolish way, or because of being foolish
dictionaryExamples: Foolishly, I didn't write the phone number down.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was fourteen and foolishly in love with a blonde girl [in] my class to whom I had only spoken twice. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: one of the two flat parts on the ends of your legs that you stand on
dictionaryExamples: I've hurt my left foot.
bare feet
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then, in just a few minutes, we are going to put our feet in the hot sand. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: walking
dictionaryExamples: Are you riding your bicycle or going on foot?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It isn't far away from the main building [-] it's about 15 minutes on foot. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: a unit of measurement, equal to twelve inches or 0.3048 meters
dictionaryExamples: The man was standing only a few feet away.
She is five feet, three inches/5′ 3″ tall.
She is five foot three.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The room is about 150 square feet, rectangular in shape, with a window opposite the door and a pair of sliding doors to the balcony at one end. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: the bottom of something such as stairs, a hill, a bed, or a page
dictionaryExamples: Put the notes at the foot of the page.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every year, expedition-groups from almost every country met at the foot of the highest mountain in the world to conquer it. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: to go into a place or onto a piece of land
dictionaryExamples: He told me never to set foot in his house again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I dream of being the first one to set foot on a white sandy beach, to admire a new kind of vegetation: cranberry bushes, sweet potatoes, wild turkeys, a different climate; how scary and exciting at the same time! Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: to tell someone in a strong way that they must do something or must stop doing something
dictionaryExamples: When she started borrowing my clothes without asking, I had to put my foot down.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, I would like to appeal to other readers of the "Cyprus Weekly," who might even be living near my area, to put your foot down and apply any pressure you can on people who can do something about the situation. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to relax, especially by sitting with your feet supported above the ground
dictionaryExamples: Put your feet up for half an hour before the kids get home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You have done your work and now you can put your feet up. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

blocks.phrase: put your foot in your mouth

sense.def: to say something you should not say, especially something embarrassing
dictionaryExamples: He makes outrageous comments and is always putting his foot in his mouth.

blocks.phrase: get/start off on the wrong foot

sense.def: to start a relationship or activity badly
dictionaryExamples: He got off on the wrong foot with my parents by arriving late.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One of the greatest pleasure[s] of reading "The Remains of the Day" would be to see the gradual development of the relationship between Stevens and Miss Kenton. From the beginning, they get off on the wrong foot. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: to stand up after you have been sitting
dictionaryExamples: The audience rose to their feet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The capacity crowd rose to their feet to cheer Dylan and his band; since then I understood why his fans worship him like a god. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to pay for something that costs a lot of money
dictionaryExamples: His parents can’t afford to foot the bill for his college education.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Only one problem arouse, which is who is going to foot the bill because such a factory is quite expensive. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: an oval ball made of leather or plastic and filled with air, used in playing football
dictionaryExamples: They were tossing around a football.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'll get a new football for you. Key English Test; A2; Arabic

sense.def: a game in which two teams of players kick, throw, and run with an oval ball to cross a goal line and score points
dictionaryExamples: a football player/team/helmet
He's playing football.
Are you coming to the football game?
I'm a big football fan.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now I'm very happy, we play football, baseball but it's very difficult to speak all the time in English. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: the game of soccer
dictionaryExamples: He played football in Spain.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I got two tickets for [the] football match. Key English Test; A2; Slovene

sense.def: the sound of a foot hitting the ground when someone walks
dictionaryExamples: I heard footsteps behind me and quickly turned around.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We are lucky that it is summer now with warm and sunny weather.  In Stockholm people  are walking - the streets are [thi]ck with people and you can even hear their footsteps! Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: to do the same things in your life as someone else did, especially a member of your family
dictionaryExamples: He followed in his father's footsteps and became an actor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Her step-granddaughter gets fascinated with Olivia's story and this fascination draws her to India to follow in her footsteps. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: intended to be given to or used by someone or something
dictionaryExamples: There's a message for you.
I'd better buy something for the new baby.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is my information for you. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French

sense.def: used to show an amount of time or distance
dictionaryExamples: She's out of the office for a few days next week.
I'm just going to rest for an hour or so.
I haven't played tennis for years.
We drove for miles without seeing anyone.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had a break for 20 minutes. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese

sense.def: used to give an example of the type of thing you mean
dictionaryExamples: I like soft fruit, for example, peaches and plums.
Some people, students for example, can get cheaper tickets.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can make a quick snack, for example a sandwich. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; German

sense.def: having a particular purpose
dictionaryExamples: There's a sign there saying "boats for rent."
Which vitamins should you take for  skin problems?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You [need] to bring your exer[c]ise book for art. Key English Test; A2; Russian

sense.def: in order to get or achieve something
dictionaryExamples: I hate waiting for the bus.
I had to run for the bus.
Did you send off for an application?
I've applied for a job with another computer company.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's important to me because I['m] going to study for an exam. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: in exchange for something, especially an amount of money
dictionaryExamples: How much did you pay for your glasses?
She sold the house for quite a lot of money.
They've said they'll repair my car for $300.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I['m] sell[ing] it for 100 Euro. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: on the occasion of
dictionaryExamples: What did you buy him for Christmas?
We're having a party for Jim's 60th birthday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm tired because I ha[d] a party yesterday for my birthday. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: at a particular time
dictionaryExamples: I made a reservation at the restaurant for nine o'clock.
We can give you an appointment for 10:15.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Can we rearrange the time for five o'clock? Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: because of or as a result of something
dictionaryExamples: He got fined for leaving his car in a no-parking zone.
The things you do for love!
Scotland is famous for its beautiful countryside.
He's best remembered for his novels.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is famous for "paella" but we have many dif[f]erent kind[s] of food. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Spanish

sense.def: showing meaning
dictionaryExamples: What's the Czech word for "book"?
"What does J. L. stand for?" "José Luis."

sense.def: toward or in the direction of
dictionaryExamples: They looked as if they were heading for the train station.
Just follow signs for Cleveland.
This time tomorrow we'll be setting off for Peru.

sense.def: available to buy
dictionaryExamples: Is this painting for sale?
Our neighbors put their house up for sale  last week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For sale: "Olympus" camera + bag. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: in order to help someone
dictionaryExamples: I'll carry those bags for you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'd like to do something helpful for them. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: being employed by or representing a company, country, etc.
dictionaryExamples: She works for a charity.
He plays soccer for D.C. United.
He used to swim for his school team when he was younger.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He works for a company in Mexico. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: always in the future
dictionaryExamples: I'm not going to live here for ever.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My friend  was leaving the city for ever and [going] to a city in another country. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

blocks.phrase: for fun or for the fun of it

sense.def: for pleasure and not for any other reason
dictionaryExamples: I ran but just for fun.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Fortunately I discovered that [the e-mail] wasn't for me. I didn't appreciate that there were people that were sending things like that just for fun. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: without any doubt
dictionaryExamples: I think he's Canadian but I don't know for sure.
One thing's for sure - once the baby's born, your lives will never be the same again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For sure, you'll love Brazil. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: for example
dictionaryExamples: In the electronics industry, for instance, 5000 people lost their jobs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For instance, you can do mountain walks. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: in support of or in agreement with
dictionaryExamples: I voted for the him at the last election.
So let's hear some applause for these talented young performers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are a lot of votes for and against keeping animals in cages. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: If you do something for the moment, you are doing it now, but might do something different in the future.
dictionaryExamples: Let's continue with what we already decided for the moment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For the moment I am unemployed so I have plenty of time to give [you] a hand. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: used to mean that something is happening that does not usually happen
dictionaryExamples: For once, the bus was on time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We would take lots of pictures, and play our own instruments, and if we get lucky enough, we would even touch the very stones and for once be embraced by magic itself. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: taken seriously, not pretended
dictionaryExamples: I thought it was just a practice, but apparently it was for real.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You know I am a Casanova, but this time I know [it] is for real. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: used to say whose responsibility something is
dictionaryExamples: I can't tell you whether you should go or not - that's for you to decide.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is for you to decide whet[h]er my colleagues should take part in this kind of course or not, but all in all I would like to recommend this course. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: when compared to a particular fact
dictionaryExamples: She's quite tall for her age.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She spends all day indoors "stuffing" her craving for knowledge with books quite hard for her age. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: forever
dictionaryExamples: When he was 20, he left home for good.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was renting this property previously, but he went back to Sri Lanka for good. International English Language Testing System; C1; Singhalese

sense.def: for the whole of someone's life
dictionaryExamples: I will have to take this medicine for life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A wedding opens a new life when the two parties commit to each other for life. International English Language Testing System; C1; French

sense.def: for a long time
dictionaryExamples: We didn't have to wait for long.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My parents' generation, however, would not identi[f]y with this lifestyle for long. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: mostly or usually
dictionaryExamples: I enjoyed it for the most part.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, for the most part, people have to use computers in their jobs. International English Language Testing System; C1; French

sense.def: despite
dictionaryExamples: For all her qualifications, she's useless at the job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For all of his desire to be strong, Okonkwo is haunted [by] fear. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: If something is for the best, it seems unpleasant now, but will improve a situation in the future.
dictionaryExamples: Moving to a smaller apartment really was for the best.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's a kind of sad thing to think about but maybe it's for the best. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: because you are worried about something/doing something
dictionaryExamples: I didn't want to move for fear of waking her up.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: No one dared to turn around for fear of being bitterly disappointed. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: used to give a reason for something
dictionaryExamples: You can't give Amy that shirt - for one thing it wont fit her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, for one thing, you cannot spy on your subjects 24 hours a day - they would not allow it, and it would be prohibitively expensive. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to order someone not to do something, or to say that something must not happen
dictionaryExamples: I forbid you to see that boy again!
The law forbids the sale of cigarettes to underage people.
He is forbidden from leaving the country.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They forbid people talking in the same room where they watch TV. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: not allowed, especially by law
dictionaryExamples: Smoking is forbidden in the theater.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She explained to me how this school works, what is allowed and what is forbidden. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: physical strength or power
dictionaryExamples: The force of the wind had brought down a great many trees in the area.
The army seized power by force.
Teachers aren't allowed to use force in controlling their pupils.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I understood that someone had entered [my house] by force and had stolen my television. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a group of people organized to work together for a particular purpose, for example in military service
dictionaryExamples: the security forces
the work force
He joined the police force straight out of high school.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Donald Wood [was] risking his life and that of his family in the process of reporting the vile crimes of the SA. police force. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: power and influence, or a person or thing that has it
dictionaryExamples: the forces of good/evil
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Each boy is a battleground where the forces of confusion wage war on the forces of good. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

blocks.phrase: a force to be reckoned with

sense.def: a very powerful person or organization
dictionaryExamples: His Dad is a force to be reckoned with.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: No longer a remote, backward, unimportant country, it became a force to be reckoned with in Europe. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: When two people or groups join forces, they act or work together.
dictionaryExamples: She joined forces with her sister-in-law to set up a restaurant.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The second proposal is that we join forces with Green Peace in picketing the refinery, this of course is up to the individual members. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: If a law, rule, etc. is in force, it exists and is being used.
dictionaryExamples: New regulations limiting fishing on this river are now in force.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Because the measures are only in Patra they are not very powerful because it isn't an official law so that it is always in force. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: all of the people available to work or actually employed in a particular area, industry, or company
dictionaryExamples: In this city, over 15 percent of the labor force are in jobs that require a bachelor's degree.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Young couples usually don't want to have more then one or two [children] and the labor force is declining. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to make someone do something that they do not want to do
dictionaryExamples: You can't force her to make a decision.
I had to force myself to finish the game.
I didn't actually want any more dessert, but Julia forced it on me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: By participating in such games you force yourself to do your best. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to use physical strength or effort to make something move or open
dictionaryExamples: Move your leg up gently when you're doing this exercise, but don't force it.
If you force the zipper, it'll break.
She forced the window open.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They forced the door, entered the house and found Mary under the effect of drugs and h[er] boyfriend on the floor dead. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: expressing opinions strongly and demanding attention or action
dictionaryExamples: a forceful manner/personality
