sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But she was a forceful woman who knew how to deal with her problems. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a report saying what the weather is likely to be like
dictionaryExamples: The weather forecast said it was going to rain later today.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The weather forecast is not so good for the next two days: rain and wind. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swedish

sense.def: the flat part of the face, above the eyes and below the hair
dictionaryExamples: She's got a high forehead.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suddenly, the girl found herself in front of the man, holding a gun against her forehead. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: belonging or connected to a country that is not your own
dictionaryExamples: Spain was the first foreign country she had visited.
foreign languages
His work provided him with the opportunity for a lot of foreign travel.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You know I have got a friend in Germany, but I want to meet more foreign people. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: relating to or dealing with countries that are not your own
dictionaryExamples: foreign policy
the 	foreign secretary
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is also extrao[r]dinary in that she graduated from Harvard University and Tokyo University and used to work for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs as a senior civil servant. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: to be something you know nothing about or do not understand
dictionaryExamples: The concept of loyalty is completely foreign to him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But, vulgarity was foreign to his nature and he seemed to be merely a shy man. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: a person who comes from another country
dictionaryExamples: I was so obviously a foreigner.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I started my new English class last week, because I really want to master English for my dream, to teach Japanese for foreigners. Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese

sense.def: to expect a future situation or event
dictionaryExamples: I don't foresee any problems in the future.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Our duty is to foresee any complication before it appears. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: a large area of trees growing closely together
dictionaryExamples: the Black Forest
The children got lost in the forest.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  I would like [to] go for a walk in the forest. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: for all time in the future
dictionaryExamples: I'll love you forever.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'll keep it forever in my memory! Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: for an extremely long time or too much time
dictionaryExamples: We'd better walk a bit quicker - it's going to take forever if we go this slowly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It would take forever. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: an illegal copy of a document, painting, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The passport was clearly a forgery.

sense.def: the crime of making an illegal copy of something
dictionaryExamples: The doctor was convicted on two charges of forgery.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Frank remembered his dark past, when he commit[t]ed forgery. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to decide not to be angry with someone for something they have done, or not to punish them for something they have done
dictionaryExamples: She never forgave her mother for lying to her.
He had betrayed her and she never forgave him.
I'd never forgive myself if anything happened to the kids.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will never forgive him. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: used before you ask or say something that might seem rude
dictionaryExamples: Forgive me for asking, but how much did you pay for your bag?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Forgive me if I have made it seem so funny, but I'm telling you you should have seen his face. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: when you forgive someone for something they have done
dictionaryExamples: They begged her for forgiveness.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She gave me a panicked look of abashment and begged for my forgiveness. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a small object with three or four points and a handle, that you use to pick up food and eat with
dictionaryExamples: a knife and fork.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like a clean fork and knife. Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: a document with spaces for you to write information
dictionaryExamples: an application form
an entry form
Please fill in/out the form with black ink.
When you have completed the form, hand it in at the desk.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My job application form is in that file. Key English Test; A2; Tamil

sense.def: a way of writing or saying a word that shows if it is singular or plural, past or present, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The continuous form of "stand" is "standing."
"Hers" is the possessive form of "her."
"Isn't" is the short form of "is not."

sense.def: a type of something
dictionaryExamples: Swimming is the best form of exercise.
a rare form of cancer
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Bicycle fans say that cycling is a very good form of exercise. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: the particular way in which something appears or exists
dictionaryExamples: The novel is written in the form of a series of letters.
The medicine comes in the form of a liquid or pills.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For all this, I can only say that I want my money back immediately, or [some] compensation in the form of a real trip to a real country. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: feeling or performing well
dictionaryExamples: He was in great form and won the golf tournament by 7 strokes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In this period of time the sportsman or -women has to constantly concentrate on being in top form, as well as dealing with the heavy amount of publicity that comes with being a "superstar." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: to make something by combining different parts
dictionaryExamples: In English, you form the present participle by adding -ing to the verb.

sense.def: to begin to exist or to make something begin to exist
dictionaryExamples: We are learning more about how stars are formed.
A solution began to form in her mind.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You [are] only [attached] to material values and your life-style is formed by earning money. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to start an organization or business
dictionaryExamples: She formed her own company eleven years ago.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many organizations were formed to protect the now endangered species, and people began to ask themselves: are zoos necessary? First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to take or to make something take a particular shape
dictionaryExamples: Hold hands and form a circle.
Form the dough into little balls.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The girl's mother had baked the biggest cake the little girl had ever seen and covered it with a lot of cream, and 10 lighted candles formed a heart in the middle. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to begin to have a particular opinion or idea about something because of the information you have
dictionaryExamples: I formed the opinion that I was not really welcome there any more.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Young people are at the mercy of several ide[o]logical spectrums that dominate them and prevent them from forming an objective opinion. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to be the thing talked about or be part of it
dictionaryExamples: The Alps form a natural barrier between Italy and Switzerland.
Her diary forms the basis of the book.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Someone tried to drink the water that had formed a puddle [o]n the ground but ended up with a mouthful of moist yellow-tinted mud. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: describes language, clothes and behavior that are traditional and correct
dictionaryExamples: a formal dinner party
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You don't need to wear formal clothes. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: Formal education, training, etc., is learning in an established course in a school.
dictionaryExamples: His formal education ended at the sixth grade, yet he became a millionaire at the age of thirty.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I never had any formal training in computers but I know how to operate the system, to make files and to use [the] Internet. International English Language Testing System; C1; Panjabi

sense.def: public or official
dictionaryExamples: a formal announcement/request
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For that reason, I have to ask you for a formal apology in print, where you could give the correct version of events and also change the bad image you gave to the readers of the people of my organi[z]ation. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: officially
dictionaryExamples: The deal will be formally announced on Tuesday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all I'll tell you a little about the ceremony. It's usually held in a church, (in our case, a Catholic one as we are Catholics); the priest reads some parts of the Bible to the bridegroom (that's usually chosen before with the couple); then they exchange rings and they'll be formally married. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: in a polite way
dictionaryExamples: They shook hands formally.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On New Year's Day all members in a family got together (members who lived separately came home), greeted [each other] more formally than usual, and ate the special food. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: the way something is designed, arranged, or produced
dictionaryExamples: This year's event will have a new format.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is one particular format which has been consistently on air almost without any adjustments: the soap opera. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German

sense.def: the development of something into a particular thing or shape
dictionaryExamples: the formation of a crystal
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Due to the heat from the sun, the sea water evaporates and this leads to the formation of clouds as the water condenses as it gets higher. International English Language Testing System; C2; Malayalam

sense.def: when something has a particular shape or things are arranged in a particular way
dictionaryExamples: rock/cloud formations
The planes flew overhead in formation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The cave had the most incredible ice formation I had ever seen. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: happening, existing or true in the past but not now
dictionaryExamples: his former wife
a former employer
the former president of the United States
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And in my town [there] is also a new Italian restaurant. It's own[ed] by my mother's former colleague. Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

sense.def: the first of two people, things or groups previously mentioned
dictionaryExamples: Of the two suggestions, I prefer the former.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The former is a Chinese restaurant and the latter an Indian. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: in the past
dictionaryExamples: The European Union was formerly called the European Community.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was a hero in Japan, formerly known as the ungifted pupil from Switzerland. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: strong, powerful, and a bit frightening
dictionaryExamples: a formidable woman
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I suppose that this optimism supports her formidable pioneer-spirit and energy. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: difficult and needing a lot of effort or thought
dictionaryExamples: a formidable task
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You could feel like a fish out of water whenever you are with your colleagues or find yourself out of place and being depressed when faced with formidable tasks which are not appealing to you at all. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: a plan or method that is used to achieve something
dictionaryExamples: There's no magic formula for success.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every member of his company works as a group, rather than an individual, which is the main formula for his company's success. International English Language Testing System; C1; Urdu

sense.def: a set of letters, numbers, or symbols that express a data set, a mathematical fact, or a chemical composition
dictionaryExamples: a mathematical formula
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would be interested in learning how to do a quick search in Excel, setting up equations and establishing formula parameters for statistics operations. International English Language Testing System; C1; French

sense.def: to develop all the details of a plan for doing something
dictionaryExamples: They formulated a plan to save the company.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Having discussed this matter, we formulated three basic suggestions and we [e]valuated the advantages of each of them. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to say what you think or feel after thinking carefully
dictionaryExamples: to formulate an answer/reply
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Montag is now thinking by himself and reali[z]es that he is able to formulate his own opinion. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: happening soon
dictionaryExamples: We have just received the information about the forthcoming conference.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am writing this letter so as to give you the information which will help you organize all the necessary details of the forthcoming holiday. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: If money or help is forthcoming, it is offered or given.
dictionaryExamples: He insisted that no more money would be forthcoming.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I trust you will agree that at the very least I deserve a letter of explanation from you and a substantial refund of my money.  Unless this is forthcoming, I will have to take matters a step further. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean

sense.def: lucky
dictionaryExamples: You're very fortunate to have found such a lovely house.
It was fortunate that they had left in plenty of time.
He was fortunate in his choice of assistant.

From our point of view, we do not see how these changes will benefit the company.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The job was hard, but from my point of view, it was worth [it]. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: used to show what someone is not allowed to do or know, or what has been stopped happening
dictionaryExamples: For many years, the truth was kept from the public.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Wouldn't it be better if cars were banned from the Central Business District in order to avoid traffic jams and stress[?] First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: If something moves from side to side, it moves from left to right and back again repeatedly.
dictionaryExamples: swinging from side to side
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I began to understand it when I went [to] Kenya in 1986, because I had the wonderful chance to look at the animals in their natural [surroundings], without being in a cage, walking nervously from side to side. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: sometimes but not often
dictionaryExamples: From time to time I still think of her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I wash the dishes from time to time (I sometimes try to avoid this unpleasant duty) and clean our house. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: beginning at a particular time and continuing into the future
dictionaryExamples: The committee will meet on Monday and weekly from then onward.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: 14-24 year olds stays almost at [the] 90% attendance point before it picks up from 2008 onward. 
 International English Language Testing System; C1; Korean

sense.def: If you do something from scratch, you do it from the beginning.
dictionaryExamples: We didn't have any furniture of our own so we had to start from scratch.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That means you don't have to start from scratch with your teacher. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: completely
dictionaryExamples: I've searched the house from top to bottom and still can't find it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Very often we can see someone in black, from top to bottom, or in white. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: a line or border between two countries
dictionaryExamples: They placed guards on the frontier.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He took it and escaped towards the German frontier. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: the limits of what is known or what has been done before in an area of knowledge or activity
dictionaryExamples: the frontiers of science and technology
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Introduction: throughout history, scientists, artists and other people tried hard to push back the frontiers of knowledge, in order to succeed in making [or] creating something that all humankind will ben[e]fit from somehow. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Arabic

sense.def: a thin, white layer of ice that forms on surfaces at night when it is very cold, or a time when the temperature is very cold and water freezes
dictionaryExamples: When I woke up this morning the ground was covered with frost.
There was a frost last night.
There were a lot of hard frosts that winter.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thirdly, you do not have to worry about rain, wind, frost or other bad weather conditions. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to show on your face that you are annoyed or worried by moving your eyebrows  together
dictionaryExamples: She frowned when I mentioned his name.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She looked at him and frowned, strange, but he smiled back. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to think that something is wrong and that you should not do it
dictionaryExamples: You can wear jeans, but I think the restaurant  frowns on shorts and sneakers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Talking being very often frowned upon in the Zen gardens, consequently it is peaceful and so you can fully relax and completely empty your head. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: the expression on your face when you frown
dictionaryExamples: He looked at me with a puzzled frown.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you are truly devoted to your health, logic thus dictates that you will be sitting at the dinner table with an empty plate - and certainly a frown on your face. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: Frozen food has been made so that it will last a long time by freezing.
dictionaryExamples: We don't have any fresh vegetables, only frozen peas.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays, we do not need anymore to spend hours cooking, we just put some frozen food in the microwave, and in a few minutes our meal is ready. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: turned into ice
dictionaryExamples: They skated over the frozen lake.

sense.def: If a person, or a part of their body is frozen, they are very cold.
dictionaryExamples: Is there any heating in here? I'm frozen!
After walking through the snow, my feet were frozen stiff.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was frozen, [but] after a second I had a big silly smile on my face. Preliminary English Test; B1; Greek

sense.def: something such as an apple or orange that grows on a tree or a bush, contains seeds, and can be eaten as food
dictionaryExamples: fresh fruit
dried fruit
fruit juice
I eat three or four pieces of fruit a day.
I like exotic fruit, like mangoes and papayas.
He runs a fruit and vegetable stand at the outdoor market.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After those, maybe some fresh fruit salad with fruit juice. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: If something that someone does bears fruit, it produces successful results.
dictionaryExamples: Our decision is just beginning to bear fruit.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Being friendly at work may not necessarily be easy, but it always bears fruit. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: the good result of someone's work or actions
dictionaryExamples: The fruits of economic growth are starting to make a difference in the lives of many workers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After weeks and months of rehearsals, at last I was able to see the fruits of their work, as well as mine. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: producing good or useful results
dictionaryExamples: We had a very fruitful discussion.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We had a fruitful talk about his previous achievements in his first job, after which he found out how creative he was. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: annoyed because things are not happening in the way that you want, or in the way that they should
dictionaryExamples: I'm very frustrated at/with my lack of progress.
Fans are frustrated by their lack of success this season.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What, however, made us very frustrated was that there was no opportunity for us to take an exam at the end of this month. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: making you feel annoyed or discouraged
dictionaryExamples: a frustrating situation
It's frustrating to see money going to waste like that.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When you are working and you are in a hurry to get to your work place on time, waiting for the bus becomes quite annoying and frustrating. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: the feeling of being annoyed because things are not happening in the way that you want, or in the way that they should
dictionaryExamples: I could sense his frustration at not being able to help.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So we had to leave hungry and with a certain feeling of frustration and disappointment. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to cook food in hot oil or fat, or to be cooked in hot oil or fat
dictionaryExamples: Fry the mushrooms in a little butter.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was frying some chicken as my wife was trying to listen to the radio news. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a flat, metal pan with a long handle that is used for frying food
dictionaryExamples: Chop the mushrooms and put them in the frying pan.

sense.def: a substance that is burned to provide heat or power
dictionaryExamples: Wood, coal, oil and gas are all different kinds of fuel.
fossil fuel
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And third, if a rising number of people  use a bike instead of their car, traffic density will decrease which is, again, good for [the] environment because there [will be] fewer traffic jams [and] therefore less fuel consumption and less pollution. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: If something is fulfilling, it satisfies you and makes you happy.
dictionaryExamples: a fulfilling job
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But the choice of a fulfilling job is an important factor because most people spend 8 or 9 hours working every day and doing something that you don't like for long can be a problem. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: a feeling of happiness because you are receiving or achieving what you want in life
dictionaryExamples: Workaholics find fulfillment in their work.
I hope that you'll find happiness and fulfillment in your life together.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Having a satisfactory job, the need to seek fulfillment from material things will subside. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: the act of doing something necessary or something that you have promised or wanted to do
dictionaryExamples: Being here is the fulfillment of a lifelong ambition.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In general a success is perceived as fulfillment of som[e]one's positive role in the society. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: If a container or a space is full, it contains as many things or people as possible, or as much of something as possible.
dictionaryExamples: We couldn't get in - the theater was full.
The shelves were full of books.
The theater was only half full.
Be careful, that's a full cup of coffee I gave you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I['m] sell[ing] it, because I haven't enough free time to ride it and my garage is full! Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: complete and including every part
dictionaryExamples: Please give your full name and address.
Today's my last full day in Paris.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have Diwali holiday [which] means I will [have a] full day free. Key English Test; A2; Gujarati

sense.def: containing a lot of things or people or a lot of something
dictionaryExamples: This sweater is full of holes.
His essay was full of spelling errors.
You're always so full of energy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You could  go to Venice because it is a [special] place full of art. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: the greatest possible
dictionaryExamples: James is very bright, but he doesn't make full use of his abilities.
We were driving at full speed all the way.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You could notice he was mad about all the noise we [made].  So we left at full speed!!! Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: completely and with nothing missing
dictionaryExamples: The bill must be paid in full by the end of the month.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unfortunately, I wasn't able to read the e-mail in full, but as I underst[oo]d [it], he wanted to apologi[z]e [for] what had happened between us many years ago. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: having eaten enough food
dictionaryExamples: No more cake for me, thanks, I'm full.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After having [a] big lunch, he was full up. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: to think that you are very important in a way that annoys other people
dictionaryExamples: I doubt he even thought about what you might need, he’s so full of himself.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is a thing which I consider very important for the upbringing of my own children - to "teach" them to be coherent and to think [of] the "others" because if you are full of yourself, you are blind and you can't see what is happening around you. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to be very busy
dictionaryExamples: Shelley has her hands full with three kids under 5.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This very fact made my father work [like] a slave, as he was the only breadwinner at home, my mother having her hands full with us four. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: happening or working for the whole of the working week and not only part of it
dictionaryExamples: a full-time job
He's a  full-time student.
She went back to work full time when her youngest child went to school.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So I decided to take [a] full-time course. Preliminary English Test; B1; Croatian

sense.def: completely
dictionaryExamples: The hotel was fully booked.
Have you fully recovered from your illness?
a fully qualified teacher

sense.def: strong, unpleasant, and often dangerous gas or smoke
dictionaryExamples: car exhaust fumes
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Cars emit fumes that are very dangerous. International English Language Testing System; C1; Lithuanian

sense.def: enjoyment or pleasure, or something that gives you enjoyment or pleasure
dictionaryExamples: Have fun!
They're having lots of fun in the pool.
She's fun to be with.
I really enjoyed your party - it was a lot of fun.
It's no fun/not much fun having to work weekends.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope we have a great meal and a lot of fun. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

blocks.phrase: for fun or for the fun of it

sense.def: for pleasure and not for any other reason.
dictionaryExamples: I ran but just for fun.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Fortunately I discovered that [the e-mail] wasn't for me. I didn't appreciate that there were people that were sending things like that just for fun. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to make a joke about someone or something in an unkind way
dictionaryExamples: The other children at school used to make fun of his hair.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I didn't want to tell other people because I didn't want them to make fun of me. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: enjoyable or entertaining
dictionaryExamples: There are lots of fun things to do here.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can remember my birthday party and all the fun things we did. Key English Test; A2; Somali

sense.def: the purpose of something or the particular responsibility of someone
dictionaryExamples: Each button has a different function.
I'm not quite sure what my function is within the company.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Apart from that, zoos have got an educational function. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: a large, formal party or ceremony
dictionaryExamples: a charity function
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Almost 600 people gathered at my main wedding function. International English Language Testing System; C1; Urdu

sense.def: to work or operate
dictionaryExamples: She quickly learned how the office functions.
I’m so tired today, I can barely function.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is important to have contin[u]ous retail sales for any economy to function. International English Language Testing System; C1; Hindi

sense.def: to use for a particular purpose or in a particular way
dictionaryExamples: Our spare bedroom also functions as a study.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my point of view, the old building can function as a cafeteria for young people due to the fact that its location is in close proximity to the city center and people have the opportunity to pay a visit to the café and communicate with other people. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: designed to be practical and useful
dictionaryExamples: functional clothing
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Like many other people, I used to see my camera as a very functional object without being really fond of it. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: an amount of money collected, saved, or provided for a purpose
dictionaryExamples: a pension fund
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A fund in her name has been made for handicapped children and the amount in this fund is growing fast. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: money needed or available to spend on something
dictionaryExamples: The charity closed down due to lack of funds.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Due to the limited funds available to the commit[t]ee responsible for the festivities, the location was not in accordance with the expectations. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: to provide the money to pay for an event, activity or organization
dictionaryExamples: The company has agreed to fund my trip to Australia.
The new college is being privately funded.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This way would be a faster and more fair way to fund the changes that are to be made. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish

sense.def: relating to the most important or main part of something
dictionaryExamples: a fundamental change/difference
Training is fundamental to success.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However I liked it a lot because music is fundamental to me. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: in a basic and important way
dictionaryExamples: Nothing has fundamentally changed.
I still believe that people are fundamentally good.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Japanese gardens are fundamentally different from those designed in Europe. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: money available for a particular purpose
dictionaryExamples: The company received state funding for the project.
Doug is trying to get funding for his research.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The Club doesn't need auxiliary funding, because it uses the money from membership fees. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: a ceremony for burying or burning the body of a dead person
dictionaryExamples: The funeral will be held next Friday.
Over 300 people attended the funeral.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She was crying at his funeral. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: making you smile or laugh
dictionaryExamples: Do you know any funny stories/jokes?
I've never found Charlie Chaplin very funny.
It's a really funny movie.
It's not funny - don't laugh!
No matter how serious the situation there always seems to be a funny side to it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We dance[d], dr[a]nk coca-cola, and watch[ed] a  very funny film. Key English Test; A2; Slovak

sense.def: strange, surprising, unexpected or difficult to explain or understand
dictionaryExamples: He's got some funny ideas about how to bring up children.
That's funny - I'm sure I left my keys here.
A funny thing happened to me on the way here.
Do you think this jacket looks a bit funny with these jeans?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We often see people talking about fitness and health, [but] the funny thing for me is that everybody really looks worried about it although they don't do anything to make it better. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: the thick hair that covers the bodies of some animals, like cats or rabbits
dictionaryExamples: She stroked the rabbit's soft fur.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I find the killing of animals for fur an awful, disgusting thing. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: extremely angry
dictionaryExamples: I was late and he was furious with me.
He's furious about/at the way he's been treated.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was absolutely furious, having learned about our engagement. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: in a very angry way
dictionaryExamples: "Get out of here!" she shouted furiously.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "Put that light out", I shouted furiously after those sleepless nights. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: If a room or building is furnished, there is furniture in it.
dictionaryExamples: He's renting a fully furnished apartment by the river.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am looking for a two bedroom, fully furnished apartment. International English Language Testing System; C1; Kannada

sense.def: objects such as chairs, tables, and beds that you put into a room or building
dictionaryExamples: They have a lot of antique furniture.
The only piece of furniture he has in his room is a bed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hurt myself one week ago so I can't help you but pupils can install chairs and the [other] furniture. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: more or extra
dictionaryExamples: For further details about the offer, call this number.
Further information can be found on our website.
We'll let you know if there's any further news about the competition.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For further information, contact Joey Hung. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: additional
dictionaryExamples: A further 20 stores will open next year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As a matter of fact, only 5% of the total income was taken to pay for administration costs, and a further 10% to pay for the cost of entertainment. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: (comparative of far) at or to a place or time that is a longer distance away
dictionaryExamples: Let's walk a bit further down the road.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When we left your place we drove on the motorway to Trier and further on to Luxembourg. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: more
dictionaryExamples: He refused to discuss the matter further.
Did you get any further with your research?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I demand a full refund or I will be forced to take this mat[t]er further. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to make something develop or become more successful
dictionaryExamples: He'll do anything to further his career.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This could be because some Education graduates were already in [the]  education field and pursuing a graduate course was a means of furthering their career or knowledge. International English Language Testing System; C2; Hindi

sense.def: in addition to what has just been said
dictionaryExamples: Furthermore, we have a duty to defend our country.
Furthermore, we found that the results varied according to what time of day the sample was taken.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am 22 years of age and I have a degree in tourism. Furthermore, I have a working knowledge of English, Spanish, Catalan and Italian. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: most distant
dictionaryExamples: That's the furthest I can see without glasses.

sense.def: extreme anger or force
dictionaryExamples: The storm raged with mounting fury.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It does not happen a lot that I sit down in anger and fury to write an open letter to the "Esslebury Gazette." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: when people become excited, annoyed, or anxious about something, especially something unimportant
dictionaryExamples: What was all the fuss about?
She made a fuss when Richard spilled some coffee on her.
It's all a fuss about nothing.
We tried to arrange a ceremony with as little fuss as possible.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The Internet contains more information than any library, more easily access[i]ble and without the fuss of library cards or the risk of losing books. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: only liking particular things and very difficult to please
dictionaryExamples: She's a very fussy eater.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When visiting a foreign country it may be difficult not to be fussy about food as well, and again, that is because of habits. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: too careful about unimportant details
dictionaryExamples: He's very fussy about keeping his car clean.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And this importance of presentation and almost fussy preciseness are reflected in our tradition. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese
